en.java_lesson1_course_description: Learn the basics of Java, a strict but reliable language. Master the rules to give computers precise instructions.
en.java_lesson2_course_description: After mastering basics, dive into object-oriented programming! Learn inheritance, interfaces, and exception handling.
en.java_lesson3_course_description: Learn Java 8+ features. Stream API, lambda expressions, Optional - master modern Java.
en.java_lesson4_course_description: Learn advanced generics and collections. Write type-safe code with important concepts.
en.java_lesson5_course_description: Learn exception handling and file I/O. Essential skills for robust programs.
en.java_lesson1_ex1_slide1_content:
Java is a reliable programming language used worldwide in banks and Android apps.

Think of Java as a strict teacher - rules are tough, but they help you write safe programs with fewer mistakes.
en.java_lesson1_ex2_slide1_content:
Variables are like labeled drawers that store data.

Just like 'snack drawer' or 'toy drawer', give your variables meaningful names!
en.java_lesson1_ex3_slide1_content:
Use int (integer) for whole numbers.

Rules:
- Text -> String
- Numbers -> int
en.java_lesson1_ex4_slide1_content:
% gives the remainder of division.

Example: 10 candies shared by 3 people = 3 each, 1 remains!
en.java_lesson1_ex6_slide1_content:
Concatenation joins text and variables using +.

Like connecting puzzle pieces!
en.java_lesson1_ex7_slide1_content:
Arrays are like numbered lockers that hold data in order.

Great for shopping lists or class rosters!
en.java_lesson1_ex8_slide1_content:
Make decisions based on conditions.

Like a fork in the road - if score >= 80, pass; otherwise, fail.
en.java_lesson1_ex9_slide1_content:
else handles the alternative case.

If sunny, play outside; otherwise, play games inside.
en.java_lesson1_ex10_slide1_content:
&& (AND): both must be true
|| (OR): either can be true

Like amusement park rules: height >= 120cm AND age >= 10
en.java_lesson1_ex11_comment2: Loop through names with variable name
en.java_lesson1_ex11_slide1_content:
Loops repeat actions automatically.

Instead of calling each name individually, loop says 'call everyone in order'!
en.java_lesson1_ex12_slide1_content:
HashMap stores key-value pairs, like a dictionary.

Look up 'apple' and get 'red fruit'!
en.java_lesson1_ex13_slide1_content:
Methods are reusable code blocks with names.

Like special moves in games - call the name and it executes!
en.java_lesson2_ex1_slide1_content:
Inheritance lets a child class inherit features from a parent class.

Like inheriting eye color from parents!
en.java_lesson2_ex2_slide1_content:
Override means rewriting a parent's method in the child class.

Animals make sounds, but dogs say 'Woof!' and cats say 'Meow!'
en.java_lesson2_ex3_slide1_content:
Interface defines methods a class must have - like a contract.

If you have a driver's license (implements), you can drive (have the method)!
en.java_lesson2_ex3_slide2_content:
A class can implement multiple interfaces.

Like having both a driver's license and a cooking license!
en.java_lesson2_ex4_slide1_content:
Abstract classes are incomplete blueprints that can't be instantiated directly.

'Animal' exists but you can't create a generic 'animal' - only specific ones like dogs or cats.
en.java_lesson2_ex5_comment2: Convert string to int with parseInt
en.java_lesson2_ex5_slide1_content:
Exceptions are unexpected problems during execution.

Like running out of sugar while cooking - can't follow the recipe!
en.java_lesson2_ex6_slide1_content:
finally always runs, whether exception occurs or not.

Like always cleaning up the kitchen after cooking, success or fail!
en.java_lesson2_ex7_slide1_content:
ArrayList is a resizable list.

Like an expandable bookshelf - add or remove books freely!
en.java_lesson2_ex7_slide2_content:
ArrayList<Integer> nums = new ArrayList<>();
nums.add(10);    // Add
nums.get(0);     // Get -> 10
nums.remove(0);  // Remove
nums.size();     // Size
en.java_lesson2_ex8_slide1_content:
Enhanced for easily processes all elements.

'Wash ALL fruits in this basket' - process everything in order!
en.java_lesson2_ex9_slide1_content:
Static methods can be called without creating an instance.

Like a shared toolbox everyone can use!
en.java_lesson2_ex10_slide1_content:
Access modifiers control who can access data.

public: Anyone can access
private: Only this class
protected: Child classes too
en.java_lesson2_ex10_slide2_content:
Hide important data with private, access via methods.

Like bank accounts - can't change balance directly, must use deposit/withdraw!
en.java_lesson3_ex1_slide1_content:
Lambda expressions write functions concisely.

x -> x * 2 means 'take x, return x times 2'
en.java_lesson3_ex1_slide2_content:
() -> System.out.println("Hello")  // No params
x -> x * 2  // One param
(a, b) -> a + b  // Multiple params
en.java_lesson3_ex2_slide1_content: Stream is an API for processing collection elements in sequence.
en.java_lesson3_ex2_slide2_content:
list.stream()  // From collection
Arrays.stream(array)  // From array
Stream.of(1, 2, 3)  // From values
en.java_lesson3_ex3_slide1_content:
map applies a function to each element.

nums.stream().map(n -> n * 2) doubles each number.
en.java_lesson3_ex4_slide1_content:
filter keeps only elements matching a condition.

.filter(n -> n > 2) keeps numbers greater than 2.
en.java_lesson3_ex5_slide1_content:
collect converts Stream results to a collection.

.collect(Collectors.toList()) creates a List.
en.java_lesson3_ex5_slide2_content:
Collectors.toList()  // To List
Collectors.toSet()   // To Set
Collectors.joining(", ")  // Join strings
en.java_lesson3_ex6_slide1_content:
reduce combines all elements into one value.

.reduce(0, (a, b) -> a + b) sums all numbers.
en.java_lesson3_ex6_slide2_content:
.reduce(0, Integer::sum)  // Sum
.reduce(1, (a, b) -> a * b)  // Product
en.java_lesson3_ex7_slide1_content:
Optional represents a value that may or may not exist.

Safely handle potentially null values!
en.java_lesson3_ex7_slide2_content:
opt.orElse("default")  // Value or default
opt.ifPresent(System.out::println)  // If exists, process
en.java_lesson3_ex8_slide1_content:
:: references existing methods as lambdas.

x -> System.out.println(x) becomes System.out::println
en.java_lesson3_ex8_slide2_content:
Integer::parseInt  // Static method
System.out::println  // Instance method
String::length  // Any instance
ArrayList::new  // Constructor
en.java_lesson3_ex9_slide1_content: sorted sorts elements in natural order.
en.java_lesson4_ex1_slide1_content:
Generics let you specify types later.

Like a box that becomes 'String box' or 'Integer box' when you use it!
en.java_lesson4_ex2_comment1: Limit type upper bound with extends
en.java_lesson4_ex2_slide1_content:
extends limits which types are allowed.

<T extends Number> only accepts Number or its subclasses.
en.java_lesson4_ex2_slide2_content:
NumBox<Integer> box = new NumBox<>();  // OK
NumBox<String> box2;  // Error! String isn't a Number
en.java_lesson4_ex3_slide1_content:
? means 'any type' - like a joker card!

List<?> accepts List<String>, List<Integer>, etc.
en.java_lesson4_ex3_slide2_content:
List<? extends Number>  // Number or subclass
List<? super Integer>   // Integer or superclass
en.java_lesson4_ex4_slide1_content:
Map stores key-value pairs.

Like a phone book - look up name (key), get number (value)!
en.java_lesson4_ex4_slide2_content:
containsKey("Alice")  // Check if key exists
getOrDefault("Bob", 0)  // Default if not found
keySet()  // All keys
values()  // All values
en.java_lesson4_ex5_slide1_content:
entrySet gets all key-value pairs.

Like flipping through every page of a phone book!
en.java_lesson4_ex6_comment1: Create list with new and asList
en.java_lesson4_ex6_slide1_content:
Comparator defines how to sort.

Sort books by title, author, or year - you decide!
en.java_lesson4_ex6_slide2_content:
Comparator.naturalOrder()  // Natural order
Comparator.reverseOrder()  // Reverse
Comparator.comparing(Person::getName)  // By property
en.java_lesson4_ex7_slide1_content:
Implementing Comparable defines natural ordering for your class.

Like numbers having a natural order: 1 < 2 < 3
en.java_lesson4_ex7_slide2_content:
this < other -> negative
this == other -> 0
this > other -> positive

return this.age - other.age;
en.java_lesson4_ex8_slide1_content:
Enum defines a fixed set of constants.

Traffic lights: only RED, YELLOW, GREEN - nothing else!
en.java_lesson4_ex9_slide1_content:
Queue is FIFO (First In, First Out).

Like a line at an amusement park - first in line rides first!
en.java_lesson4_ex9_slide2_content:
offer(e)  // Add to end
poll()    // Remove from front (null if empty)
peek()    // Look at front (don't remove)
en.java_lesson4_ex10_slide1_content:
Deque (Double-Ended Queue) allows operations at both ends.

Like a train with doors at both ends!
en.java_lesson4_ex10_slide2_content:
Deque can be used as a LIFO stack.

stack.push(1);  // Push 1
stack.push(2);  // Push 2 (on top)
stack.pop();    // Pop 2 (top comes first)
en.java_lesson5_ex1_slide1_content:
Exceptions are unexpected problems during execution.

Like breaking a plate while cooking!
en.java_lesson5_ex2_slide1_content:
finally always executes, success or fail.

Always clean up the kitchen after cooking!
en.java_lesson5_ex3_slide1_content:
throws declares that a method might throw an exception.

Warning label: 'This might explode, handle with care!'
en.java_lesson5_ex3_slide2_content:
Caller must either catch or re-throw.

1. Catch it yourself
2. Pass it up with throws
en.java_lesson5_ex4_slide1_content:
Create your own exception by extending Exception.

Like custom errors: 'Age cannot be negative!'
en.java_lesson5_ex5_slide1_content:
try-with-resources automatically closes resources.

Like auto-return library books!
en.java_lesson5_ex6_slide1_content:
BufferedReader reads text efficiently.

Reads line by line instead of character by character!
en.java_lesson5_ex7_slide1_content:
BufferedWriter writes text efficiently.

Batches writes instead of one character at a time!
en.java_lesson5_ex8_slide1_content:
Scanner parses text into words and numbers.

From '10 20 30', extract 10, 20, 30 as numbers!
en.java_lesson5_ex8_slide2_content:
nextInt()    // Read integer
nextDouble() // Read decimal
next()       // Read word
nextLine()   // Read line
en.java_lesson5_ex9_slide1_content:
Java 7's Files class makes file operations easy.

Like automatic doors - easier than manual!
en.java_lesson5_ex9_slide2_content:
Files.readAllLines(path)  // Read all lines
Files.readString(path)    // Read as string
Files.write(path, lines)  // Write
Files.exists(path)        // Check existence
en.java_lesson5_ex10_slide1_content:
Use | to catch multiple exception types together.

'If apple OR orange falls, catch it!'

ja.java_lesson2_ex8_slide1_content:
# 

for 

 


cs.java_lesson1_course_description: Learn the basics of Java, a strict but reliable language. Master the rules to give computers precise instructions.
cs.java_lesson2_course_description: After mastering basics, dive into object-oriented programming! Learn inheritance, interfaces, and exception handling.
cs.java_lesson3_course_description: Learn Java 8+ features. Stream API, lambda expressions, Optional - master modern Java.
cs.java_lesson4_course_description: Learn advanced generics and collections. Write type-safe code with important concepts.
cs.java_lesson5_course_description: Learn exception handling and file I/O. Essential skills for robust programs.
cs.java_lesson1_ex1_slide1_content:
Java is a reliable programming language used worldwide in banks and Android apps.

Think of Java as a strict teacher - rules are tough, but they help you write safe programs with fewer mistakes.
cs.java_lesson1_ex2_slide1_content:
Variables are like labeled drawers that store data.

Just like 'snack drawer' or 'toy drawer', give your variables meaningful names!
cs.java_lesson1_ex3_slide1_content:
Use int (integer) for whole numbers.

Rules:
- Text -> String
- Numbers -> int
cs.java_lesson1_ex4_slide1_content:
% gives the remainder of division.

Example: 10 candies shared by 3 people = 3 each, 1 remains!
cs.java_lesson1_ex6_slide1_content:
Concatenation joins text and variables using +.

Like connecting puzzle pieces!
cs.java_lesson1_ex7_slide1_content:
Arrays are like numbered lockers that hold data in order.

Great for shopping lists or class rosters!
cs.java_lesson1_ex8_slide1_content:
Make decisions based on conditions.

Like a fork in the road - if score >= 80, pass; otherwise, fail.
cs.java_lesson1_ex9_slide1_content:
else handles the alternative case.

If sunny, play outside; otherwise, play games inside.
cs.java_lesson1_ex10_slide1_content:
&& (AND): both must be true
|| (OR): either can be true

Like amusement park rules: height >= 120cm AND age >= 10
cs.java_lesson1_ex11_comment2: Loop through names with variable name
cs.java_lesson1_ex11_slide1_content:
Loops repeat actions automatically.

Instead of calling each name individually, loop says 'call everyone in order'!
cs.java_lesson1_ex12_slide1_content:
HashMap stores key-value pairs, like a dictionary.

Look up 'apple' and get 'red fruit'!
cs.java_lesson1_ex13_slide1_content:
Methods are reusable code blocks with names.

Like special moves in games - call the name and it executes!
cs.java_lesson2_ex1_slide1_content:
Inheritance lets a child class inherit features from a parent class.

Like inheriting eye color from parents!
cs.java_lesson2_ex2_slide1_content:
Override means rewriting a parent's method in the child class.

Animals make sounds, but dogs say 'Woof!' and cats say 'Meow!'
cs.java_lesson2_ex3_slide1_content:
Interface defines methods a class must have - like a contract.

If you have a driver's license (implements), you can drive (have the method)!
cs.java_lesson2_ex3_slide2_content:
A class can implement multiple interfaces.

Like having both a driver's license and a cooking license!
cs.java_lesson2_ex4_slide1_content:
Abstract classes are incomplete blueprints that can't be instantiated directly.

'Animal' exists but you can't create a generic 'animal' - only specific ones like dogs or cats.
cs.java_lesson2_ex5_comment2: Convert string to int with parseInt
cs.java_lesson2_ex5_slide1_content:
Exceptions are unexpected problems during execution.

Like running out of sugar while cooking - can't follow the recipe!
cs.java_lesson2_ex6_slide1_content:
finally always runs, whether exception occurs or not.

Like always cleaning up the kitchen after cooking, success or fail!
cs.java_lesson2_ex7_slide1_content:
ArrayList is a resizable list.

Like an expandable bookshelf - add or remove books freely!
cs.java_lesson2_ex7_slide2_content:
ArrayList<Integer> nums = new ArrayList<>();
nums.add(10);    // Add
nums.get(0);     // Get -> 10
nums.remove(0);  // Remove
nums.size();     // Size
cs.java_lesson2_ex8_slide1_content:
Enhanced for easily processes all elements.

'Wash ALL fruits in this basket' - process everything in order!
cs.java_lesson2_ex9_slide1_content:
Static methods can be called without creating an instance.

Like a shared toolbox everyone can use!
cs.java_lesson2_ex10_slide1_content:
Access modifiers control who can access data.

public: Anyone can access
private: Only this class
protected: Child classes too
cs.java_lesson2_ex10_slide2_content:
Hide important data with private, access via methods.

Like bank accounts - can't change balance directly, must use deposit/withdraw!
cs.java_lesson3_ex1_slide1_content:
Lambda expressions write functions concisely.

x -> x * 2 means 'take x, return x times 2'
cs.java_lesson3_ex1_slide2_content:
() -> System.out.println("Hello")  // No params
x -> x * 2  // One param
(a, b) -> a + b  // Multiple params
cs.java_lesson3_ex2_slide1_content: Stream is an API for processing collection elements in sequence.
cs.java_lesson3_ex2_slide2_content:
list.stream()  // From collection
Arrays.stream(array)  // From array
Stream.of(1, 2, 3)  // From values
cs.java_lesson3_ex3_slide1_content:
map applies a function to each element.

nums.stream().map(n -> n * 2) doubles each number.
cs.java_lesson3_ex4_slide1_content:
filter keeps only elements matching a condition.

.filter(n -> n > 2) keeps numbers greater than 2.
cs.java_lesson3_ex5_slide1_content:
collect converts Stream results to a collection.

.collect(Collectors.toList()) creates a List.
cs.java_lesson3_ex5_slide2_content:
Collectors.toList()  // To List
Collectors.toSet()   // To Set
Collectors.joining(", ")  // Join strings
cs.java_lesson3_ex6_slide1_content:
reduce combines all elements into one value.

.reduce(0, (a, b) -> a + b) sums all numbers.
cs.java_lesson3_ex6_slide2_content:
.reduce(0, Integer::sum)  // Sum
.reduce(1, (a, b) -> a * b)  // Product
cs.java_lesson3_ex7_slide1_content:
Optional represents a value that may or may not exist.

Safely handle potentially null values!
cs.java_lesson3_ex7_slide2_content:
opt.orElse("default")  // Value or default
opt.ifPresent(System.out::println)  // If exists, process
cs.java_lesson3_ex8_slide1_content:
:: references existing methods as lambdas.

x -> System.out.println(x) becomes System.out::println
cs.java_lesson3_ex8_slide2_content:
Integer::parseInt  // Static method
System.out::println  // Instance method
String::length  // Any instance
ArrayList::new  // Constructor
cs.java_lesson3_ex9_slide1_content: sorted sorts elements in natural order.
cs.java_lesson4_ex1_slide1_content:
Generics let you specify types later.

Like a box that becomes 'String box' or 'Integer box' when you use it!
cs.java_lesson4_ex2_comment1: Limit type upper bound with extends
cs.java_lesson4_ex2_slide1_content:
extends limits which types are allowed.

<T extends Number> only accepts Number or its subclasses.
cs.java_lesson4_ex2_slide2_content:
NumBox<Integer> box = new NumBox<>();  // OK
NumBox<String> box2;  // Error! String isn't a Number
cs.java_lesson4_ex3_slide1_content:
? means 'any type' - like a joker card!

List<?> accepts List<String>, List<Integer>, etc.
cs.java_lesson4_ex3_slide2_content:
List<? extends Number>  // Number or subclass
List<? super Integer>   // Integer or superclass
cs.java_lesson4_ex4_slide1_content:
Map stores key-value pairs.

Like a phone book - look up name (key), get number (value)!
cs.java_lesson4_ex4_slide2_content:
containsKey("Alice")  // Check if key exists
getOrDefault("Bob", 0)  // Default if not found
keySet()  // All keys
values()  // All values
cs.java_lesson4_ex5_slide1_content:
entrySet gets all key-value pairs.

Like flipping through every page of a phone book!
cs.java_lesson4_ex6_comment1: Create list with new and asList
cs.java_lesson4_ex6_slide1_content:
Comparator defines how to sort.

Sort books by title, author, or year - you decide!
cs.java_lesson4_ex6_slide2_content:
Comparator.naturalOrder()  // Natural order
Comparator.reverseOrder()  // Reverse
Comparator.comparing(Person::getName)  // By property
cs.java_lesson4_ex7_slide1_content:
Implementing Comparable defines natural ordering for your class.

Like numbers having a natural order: 1 < 2 < 3
cs.java_lesson4_ex7_slide2_content:
this < other -> negative
this == other -> 0
this > other -> positive

return this.age - other.age;
cs.java_lesson4_ex8_slide1_content:
Enum defines a fixed set of constants.

Traffic lights: only RED, YELLOW, GREEN - nothing else!
cs.java_lesson4_ex9_slide1_content:
Queue is FIFO (First In, First Out).

Like a line at an amusement park - first in line rides first!
cs.java_lesson4_ex9_slide2_content:
offer(e)  // Add to end
poll()    // Remove from front (null if empty)
peek()    // Look at front (don't remove)
cs.java_lesson4_ex10_slide1_content:
Deque (Double-Ended Queue) allows operations at both ends.

Like a train with doors at both ends!
cs.java_lesson4_ex10_slide2_content:
Deque can be used as a LIFO stack.

stack.push(1);  // Push 1
stack.push(2);  // Push 2 (on top)
stack.pop();    // Pop 2 (top comes first)
cs.java_lesson5_ex1_slide1_content:
Exceptions are unexpected problems during execution.

Like breaking a plate while cooking!
cs.java_lesson5_ex2_slide1_content:
finally always executes, success or fail.

Always clean up the kitchen after cooking!
cs.java_lesson5_ex3_slide1_content:
throws declares that a method might throw an exception.

Warning label: 'This might explode, handle with care!'
cs.java_lesson5_ex3_slide2_content:
Caller must either catch or re-throw.

1. Catch it yourself
2. Pass it up with throws
cs.java_lesson5_ex4_slide1_content:
Create your own exception by extending Exception.

Like custom errors: 'Age cannot be negative!'
cs.java_lesson5_ex5_slide1_content:
try-with-resources automatically closes resources.

Like auto-return library books!
cs.java_lesson5_ex6_slide1_content:
BufferedReader reads text efficiently.

Reads line by line instead of character by character!
cs.java_lesson5_ex7_slide1_content:
BufferedWriter writes text efficiently.

Batches writes instead of one character at a time!
cs.java_lesson5_ex8_slide1_content:
Scanner parses text into words and numbers.

From '10 20 30', extract 10, 20, 30 as numbers!
cs.java_lesson5_ex8_slide2_content:
nextInt()    // Read integer
nextDouble() // Read decimal
next()       // Read word
nextLine()   // Read line
cs.java_lesson5_ex9_slide1_content:
Java 7's Files class makes file operations easy.

Like automatic doors - easier than manual!
cs.java_lesson5_ex9_slide2_content:
Files.readAllLines(path)  // Read all lines
Files.readString(path)    // Read as string
Files.write(path, lines)  // Write
Files.exists(path)        // Check existence
cs.java_lesson5_ex10_slide1_content:
Use | to catch multiple exception types together.

'If apple OR orange falls, catch it!'

.reduce(1, (a, b) -> a * b)  // Product
de.java_lesson3_ex7_slide1_content:
Optional represents a value that may or may not exist.

Safely handle potentially null values!
de.java_lesson3_ex7_slide2_content:
opt.orElse("default")  // Value or default
opt.ifPresent(System.out::println)  // If exists, process
de.java_lesson3_ex8_slide1_content:
:: references existing methods as lambdas.

x -> System.out.println(x) becomes System.out::println
de.java_lesson3_ex8_slide2_content:
Integer::parseInt  // Static method
System.out::println  // Instance method
String::length  // Any instance
ArrayList::new  // Constructor
de.java_lesson3_ex9_slide1_content: sorted sorts elements in natural order.
de.java_lesson4_ex1_slide1_content:
Generics let you specify types later.

Like a box that becomes 'String box' or 'Integer box' when you use it!
de.java_lesson4_ex2_comment1: Limit type upper bound with extends
de.java_lesson4_ex2_slide1_content:
extends limits which types are allowed.

<T extends Number> only accepts Number or its subclasses.
de.java_lesson4_ex2_slide2_content:
NumBox<Integer> box = new NumBox<>();  // OK
NumBox<String> box2;  // Error! String isn't a Number
de.java_lesson4_ex3_slide1_content:
? means 'any type' - like a joker card!

List<?> accepts List<String>, List<Integer>, etc.
de.java_lesson4_ex3_slide2_content:
List<? extends Number>  // Number or subclass
List<? super Integer>   // Integer or superclass
de.java_lesson4_ex4_slide1_content:
Map stores key-value pairs.

Like a phone book - look up name (key), get number (value)!
de.java_lesson4_ex4_slide2_content:
containsKey("Alice")  // Check if key exists
getOrDefault("Bob", 0)  // Default if not found
keySet()  // All keys
values()  // All values
de.java_lesson4_ex5_slide1_content:
entrySet gets all key-value pairs.

Like flipping through every page of a phone book!
de.java_lesson4_ex6_comment1: Create list with new and asList
de.java_lesson4_ex6_slide1_content:
Comparator defines how to sort.

Sort books by title, author, or year - you decide!

Comparator.reverseOrder()  // Reverse
Comparator.comparing(Person::getName)  // By property
de.java_lesson4_ex7_slide1_content:
Implementing Comparable defines natural ordering for your class.

Like numbers having a natural order: 1 < 2 < 3
de.java_lesson4_ex7_slide2_content:
this < other -> negative
this == other -> 0
this > other -> positive

return this.age - other.age;
de.java_lesson4_ex8_slide1_content:
Enum defines a fixed set of constants.

Traffic lights: only RED, YELLOW, GREEN - nothing else!
de.java_lesson4_ex9_slide1_content:
Queue is FIFO (First In, First Out).

Like a line at an amusement park - first in line rides first!
de.java_lesson4_ex9_slide2_content:
offer(e)  // Add to end
poll()    // Remove from front (null if empty)
peek()    // Look at front (don't remove)
de.java_lesson4_ex10_slide1_content:
Deque (Double-Ended Queue) allows operations at both ends.

Like a train with doors at both ends!
de.java_lesson4_ex10_slide2_content:
Deque can be used as a LIFO stack.

stack.push(1);  // Push 1
stack.push(2);  // Push 2 (on top)
stack.pop();    // Pop 2 (top comes first)
de.java_lesson5_ex1_slide1_content:
Exceptions are unexpected problems during execution.

Like breaking a plate while cooking!
de.java_lesson5_ex2_slide1_content:
finally always executes, success or fail.

Always clean up the kitchen after cooking!
de.java_lesson5_ex3_slide1_content:
throws declares that a method might throw an exception.

Warning label: 'This might explode, handle with care!'
de.java_lesson5_ex3_slide2_content:
Caller must either catch or re-throw.

1. Catch it yourself
2. Pass it up with throws
de.java_lesson5_ex4_slide1_content:
Create your own exception by extending Exception.

Like custom errors: 'Age cannot be negative!'
de.java_lesson5_ex5_slide1_content:
try-with-resources automatically closes resources.

Like auto-return library books!
de.java_lesson5_ex6_slide1_content:

Reads line by line instead of character by character!

Like automatic doors - easier than manual!

nl.java_lesson1_course_description: Learn the basics of Java, a strict but reliable language. Master the rules to give computers precise instructions.
nl.java_lesson2_course_description: After mastering basics, dive into object-oriented programming! Learn inheritance, interfaces, and exception handling.
nl.java_lesson3_course_description: Learn Java 8+ features. Stream API, lambda expressions, Optional - master modern Java.
nl.java_lesson4_course_description: Learn advanced generics and collections. Write type-safe code with important concepts.
nl.java_lesson5_course_description: Learn exception handling and file I/O. Essential skills for robust programs.
nl.java_lesson1_ex1_slide1_content:
Java is a reliable programming language used worldwide in banks and Android apps.

Think of Java as a strict teacher - rules are tough, but they help you write safe programs with fewer mistakes.
nl.java_lesson1_ex2_slide1_content:
Variables are like labeled drawers that store data.

Just like 'snack drawer' or 'toy drawer', give your variables meaningful names!
nl.java_lesson1_ex3_slide1_content:
Use int (integer) for whole numbers.

Rules:
- Text -> String
- Numbers -> int
nl.java_lesson1_ex4_slide1_content:
% gives the remainder of division.

Example: 10 candies shared by 3 people = 3 each, 1 remains!
nl.java_lesson1_ex6_slide1_content:
Concatenation joins text and variables using +.

Like connecting puzzle pieces!
nl.java_lesson1_ex7_slide1_content:
Arrays are like numbered lockers that hold data in order.

Great for shopping lists or class rosters!
nl.java_lesson1_ex8_slide1_content:
Make decisions based on conditions.

Like a fork in the road - if score >= 80, pass; otherwise, fail.
nl.java_lesson1_ex9_slide1_content:
else handles the alternative case.

If sunny, play outside; otherwise, play games inside.
nl.java_lesson1_ex10_slide1_content:
&& (AND): both must be true
|| (OR): either can be true

Like amusement park rules: height >= 120cm AND age >= 10
nl.java_lesson1_ex11_comment2: Loop through names with variable name
nl.java_lesson1_ex11_slide1_content:
Loops repeat actions automatically.

Instead of calling each name individually, loop says 'call everyone in order'!
nl.java_lesson1_ex12_slide1_content:
HashMap stores key-value pairs, like a dictionary.

Look up 'apple' and get 'red fruit'!
nl.java_lesson1_ex13_slide1_content:
Methods are reusable code blocks with names.

Like special moves in games - call the name and it executes!
nl.java_lesson2_ex1_slide1_content:
Inheritance lets a child class inherit features from a parent class.

Like inheriting eye color from parents!
nl.java_lesson2_ex2_slide1_content:
Override means rewriting a parent's method in the child class.

Animals make sounds, but dogs say 'Woof!' and cats say 'Meow!'
nl.java_lesson2_ex3_slide1_content:
Interface defines methods a class must have - like a contract.

If you have a driver's license (implements), you can drive (have the method)!
nl.java_lesson2_ex3_slide2_content:
A class can implement multiple interfaces.

Like having both a driver's license and a cooking license!
nl.java_lesson2_ex4_slide1_content:
Abstract classes are incomplete blueprints that can't be instantiated directly.

'Animal' exists but you can't create a generic 'animal' - only specific ones like dogs or cats.
nl.java_lesson2_ex5_comment2: Convert string to int with parseInt
nl.java_lesson2_ex5_slide1_content:
Exceptions are unexpected problems during execution.

Like running out of sugar while cooking - can't follow the recipe!
nl.java_lesson2_ex6_slide1_content:
finally always runs, whether exception occurs or not.

Like always cleaning up the kitchen after cooking, success or fail!
nl.java_lesson2_ex7_slide1_content:
ArrayList is a resizable list.

Like an expandable bookshelf - add or remove books freely!
nl.java_lesson2_ex7_slide2_content:
ArrayList<Integer> nums = new ArrayList<>();
nums.add(10);    // Add
nums.get(0);     // Get -> 10
nums.remove(0);  // Remove
nums.size();     // Size
nl.java_lesson2_ex8_slide1_content:
Enhanced for easily processes all elements.

'Wash ALL fruits in this basket' - process everything in order!
nl.java_lesson2_ex9_slide1_content:
Static methods can be called without creating an instance.

Like a shared toolbox everyone can use!
nl.java_lesson2_ex10_slide1_content:
Access modifiers control who can access data.

public: Anyone can access
private: Only this class
protected: Child classes too
nl.java_lesson2_ex10_slide2_content:
Hide important data with private, access via methods.

Like bank accounts - can't change balance directly, must use deposit/withdraw!
nl.java_lesson3_ex1_slide1_content:
Lambda expressions write functions concisely.

x -> x * 2 means 'take x, return x times 2'
nl.java_lesson3_ex1_slide2_content:
() -> System.out.println("Hello")  // No params
x -> x * 2  // One param
(a, b) -> a + b  // Multiple params
nl.java_lesson3_ex2_slide1_content: Stream is an API for processing collection elements in sequence.
nl.java_lesson3_ex2_slide2_content:
list.stream()  // From collection
Arrays.stream(array)  // From array
Stream.of(1, 2, 3)  // From values
nl.java_lesson3_ex3_slide1_content:
map applies a function to each element.

nums.stream().map(n -> n * 2) doubles each number.
nl.java_lesson3_ex4_slide1_content:
filter keeps only elements matching a condition.

.filter(n -> n > 2) keeps numbers greater than 2.
nl.java_lesson3_ex5_slide1_content:
collect converts Stream results to a collection.

.collect(Collectors.toList()) creates a List.
nl.java_lesson3_ex5_slide2_content:
Collectors.toList()  // To List
Collectors.toSet()   // To Set
Collectors.joining(", ")  // Join strings
nl.java_lesson3_ex6_slide1_content:
reduce combines all elements into one value.

.reduce(0, (a, b) -> a + b) sums all numbers.
nl.java_lesson3_ex6_slide2_content:
.reduce(0, Integer::sum)  // Sum
.reduce(1, (a, b) -> a * b)  // Product
nl.java_lesson3_ex7_slide1_content:
Optional represents a value that may or may not exist.

Safely handle potentially null values!
nl.java_lesson3_ex7_slide2_content:
opt.orElse("default")  // Value or default
opt.ifPresent(System.out::println)  // If exists, process
nl.java_lesson3_ex8_slide1_content:
:: references existing methods as lambdas.

x -> System.out.println(x) becomes System.out::println
nl.java_lesson3_ex8_slide2_content:
Integer::parseInt  // Static method
System.out::println  // Instance method
String::length  // Any instance
ArrayList::new  // Constructor
nl.java_lesson3_ex9_slide1_content: sorted sorts elements in natural order.
nl.java_lesson4_ex1_slide1_content:
Generics let you specify types later.

Like a box that becomes 'String box' or 'Integer box' when you use it!
nl.java_lesson4_ex2_comment1: Limit type upper bound with extends
nl.java_lesson4_ex2_slide1_content:
extends limits which types are allowed.

<T extends Number> only accepts Number or its subclasses.

NumBox<String> box2;  // Error! String isn't a Number
nl.java_lesson4_ex3_slide1_content:
? means 'any type' - like a joker card!

List<?> accepts List<String>, List<Integer>, etc.
nl.java_lesson4_ex3_slide2_content:
List<? extends Number>  // Number or subclass
List<? super Integer>   // Integer or superclass
nl.java_lesson4_ex4_slide1_content:
Map stores key-value pairs.

Like a phone book - look up name (key), get number (value)!
nl.java_lesson4_ex4_slide2_content:
containsKey("Alice")  // Check if key exists
getOrDefault("Bob", 0)  // Default if not found
keySet()  // All keys
values()  // All values
nl.java_lesson4_ex5_slide1_content:
entrySet gets all key-value pairs.

Like flipping through every page of a phone book!

Sort books by title, author, or year - you decide!

Exceptions are unexpected problems during execution.

Like breaking a plate while cooking!
nl.java_lesson5_ex2_slide1_content:
finally always executes, success or fail.

Always clean up the kitchen after cooking!

Warning label: 'This might explode, handle with care!'

'Wash ALL fruits in this basket' - process everything in order!
da.java_lesson2_ex9_slide1_content:
Static methods can be called without creating an instance.

Like a shared toolbox everyone can use!
da.java_lesson2_ex10_slide1_content:
Access modifiers control who can access data.

public: Anyone can access
private: Only this class
protected: Child classes too
da.java_lesson2_ex10_slide2_content:
Hide important data with private, access via methods.

Like bank accounts - can't change balance directly, must use deposit/withdraw!
da.java_lesson3_ex1_slide1_content:
Lambda expressions write functions concisely.

x -> x * 2 means 'take x, return x times 2'
da.java_lesson3_ex1_slide2_content:
() -> System.out.println("Hello")  // No params
x -> x * 2  // One param
(a, b) -> a + b  // Multiple params
da.java_lesson3_ex2_slide1_content: Stream is an API for processing collection elements in sequence.
da.java_lesson3_ex2_slide2_content:
list.stream()  // From collection
Arrays.stream(array)  // From array
Stream.of(1, 2, 3)  // From values
da.java_lesson3_ex3_slide1_content:
map applies a function to each element.

nums.stream().map(n -> n * 2) doubles each number.
da.java_lesson3_ex4_slide1_content:
filter keeps only elements matching a condition.

.filter(n -> n > 2) keeps numbers greater than 2.
da.java_lesson3_ex5_slide1_content:
collect converts Stream results to a collection.

.collect(Collectors.toList()) creates a List.
da.java_lesson3_ex5_slide2_content:
Collectors.toList()  // To List
Collectors.toSet()   // To Set
Collectors.joining(", ")  // Join strings
da.java_lesson3_ex6_slide1_content:
reduce combines all elements into one value.

.reduce(0, (a, b) -> a + b) sums all numbers.
da.java_lesson3_ex6_slide2_content:
.reduce(0, Integer::sum)  // Sum
.reduce(1, (a, b) -> a * b)  // Product
da.java_lesson3_ex7_slide1_content:
Optional represents a value that may or may not exist.

Safely handle potentially null values!
da.java_lesson3_ex7_slide2_content:
opt.orElse("default")  // Value or default
opt.ifPresent(System.out::println)  // If exists, process
da.java_lesson3_ex8_slide1_content:
:: references existing methods as lambdas.

x -> System.out.println(x) becomes System.out::println
da.java_lesson3_ex8_slide2_content:
Integer::parseInt  // Static method
System.out::println  // Instance method
String::length  // Any instance
ArrayList::new  // Constructor
da.java_lesson3_ex9_slide1_content: sorted sorts elements in natural order.
da.java_lesson4_ex1_slide1_content:
Generics let you specify types later.

Like a box that becomes 'String box' or 'Integer box' when you use it!
da.java_lesson4_ex2_comment1: Limit type upper bound with extends
da.java_lesson4_ex2_slide1_content:
extends limits which types are allowed.

<T extends Number> only accepts Number or its subclasses.
da.java_lesson4_ex2_slide2_content:
NumBox<Integer> box = new NumBox<>();  // OK
NumBox<String> box2;  // Error! String isn't a Number
da.java_lesson4_ex3_slide1_content:
? means 'any type' - like a joker card!

List<?> accepts List<String>, List<Integer>, etc.
da.java_lesson4_ex3_slide2_content:
List<? extends Number>  // Number or subclass
List<? super Integer>   // Integer or superclass
da.java_lesson4_ex4_slide1_content:
Map stores key-value pairs.

Like a phone book - look up name (key), get number (value)!
da.java_lesson4_ex4_slide2_content:
containsKey("Alice")  // Check if key exists
getOrDefault("Bob", 0)  // Default if not found
keySet()  // All keys
values()  // All values
da.java_lesson4_ex5_slide1_content:
entrySet gets all key-value pairs.

Like flipping through every page of a phone book!
da.java_lesson4_ex6_comment1: Create list with new and asList
da.java_lesson4_ex6_slide1_content:
Comparator defines how to sort.

Sort books by title, author, or year - you decide!
da.java_lesson4_ex6_slide2_content:
Comparator.naturalOrder()  // Natural order
Comparator.reverseOrder()  // Reverse
Comparator.comparing(Person::getName)  // By property
da.java_lesson4_ex7_slide1_content:
Implementing Comparable defines natural ordering for your class.

Like numbers having a natural order: 1 < 2 < 3
da.java_lesson4_ex7_slide2_content:
this < other -> negative
this == other -> 0
this > other -> positive

return this.age - other.age;
da.java_lesson4_ex8_slide1_content:
Enum defines a fixed set of constants.

Traffic lights: only RED, YELLOW, GREEN - nothing else!
da.java_lesson4_ex9_slide1_content:
Queue is FIFO (First In, First Out).

Like a line at an amusement park - first in line rides first!
da.java_lesson4_ex9_slide2_content:
offer(e)  // Add to end
poll()    // Remove from front (null if empty)
peek()    // Look at front (don't remove)
da.java_lesson4_ex10_slide1_content:
Deque (Double-Ended Queue) allows operations at both ends.

Like a train with doors at both ends!
da.java_lesson4_ex10_slide2_content:
Deque can be used as a LIFO stack.

stack.push(1);  // Push 1
stack.push(2);  // Push 2 (on top)
stack.pop();    // Pop 2 (top comes first)
da.java_lesson5_ex1_slide1_content:
Exceptions are unexpected problems during execution.

Like breaking a plate while cooking!
da.java_lesson5_ex2_slide1_content:
finally always executes, success or fail.

Always clean up the kitchen after cooking!
da.java_lesson5_ex3_slide1_content:
throws declares that a method might throw an exception.

Warning label: 'This might explode, handle with care!'
da.java_lesson5_ex3_slide2_content:
Caller must either catch or re-throw.

1. Catch it yourself
2. Pass it up with throws
da.java_lesson5_ex4_slide1_content:
Create your own exception by extending Exception.

Like custom errors: 'Age cannot be negative!'
da.java_lesson5_ex5_slide1_content:
try-with-resources automatically closes resources.

Like auto-return library books!
da.java_lesson5_ex6_slide1_content:
BufferedReader reads text efficiently.

Reads line by line instead of character by character!
da.java_lesson5_ex7_slide1_content:
BufferedWriter writes text efficiently.

Batches writes instead of one character at a time!
da.java_lesson5_ex8_slide1_content:
Scanner parses text into words and numbers.

From '10 20 30', extract 10, 20, 30 as numbers!
da.java_lesson5_ex8_slide2_content:
nextInt()    // Read integer
nextDouble() // Read decimal
next()       // Read word
nextLine()   // Read line
da.java_lesson5_ex9_slide1_content:
Java 7's Files class makes file operations easy.

Like automatic doors - easier than manual!
da.java_lesson5_ex9_slide2_content:
Files.readAllLines(path)  // Read all lines
Files.readString(path)    // Read as string
Files.write(path, lines)  // Write
Files.exists(path)        // Check existence
da.java_lesson5_ex10_slide1_content:
Use | to catch multiple exception types together.

'If apple OR orange falls, catch it!'

Deque

el.java_lesson1_course_description: Learn the basics of Java, a strict but reliable language. Master the rules to give computers precise instructions.
el.java_lesson2_course_description: After mastering basics, dive into object-oriented programming! Learn inheritance, interfaces, and exception handling.
el.java_lesson3_course_description: Learn Java 8+ features. Stream API, lambda expressions, Optional - master modern Java.
el.java_lesson4_course_description: Learn advanced generics and collections. Write type-safe code with important concepts.
el.java_lesson5_course_description: Learn exception handling and file I/O. Essential skills for robust programs.
el.java_lesson1_ex1_slide1_content:
Java is a reliable programming language used worldwide in banks and Android apps.

Think of Java as a strict teacher - rules are tough, but they help you write safe programs with fewer mistakes.
el.java_lesson1_ex2_slide1_content:
Variables are like labeled drawers that store data.

Just like 'snack drawer' or 'toy drawer', give your variables meaningful names!
el.java_lesson1_ex3_slide1_content:
Use int (integer) for whole numbers.

Rules:
- Text -> String
- Numbers -> int
el.java_lesson1_ex4_slide1_content:
% gives the remainder of division.

Example: 10 candies shared by 3 people = 3 each, 1 remains!
el.java_lesson1_ex6_slide1_content:
Concatenation joins text and variables using +.

Like connecting puzzle pieces!
el.java_lesson1_ex7_slide1_content:
Arrays are like numbered lockers that hold data in order.

Great for shopping lists or class rosters!
el.java_lesson1_ex8_slide1_content:
Make decisions based on conditions.

Like a fork in the road - if score >= 80, pass; otherwise, fail.
el.java_lesson1_ex9_slide1_content:
else handles the alternative case.

If sunny, play outside; otherwise, play games inside.
el.java_lesson1_ex10_slide1_content:
&& (AND): both must be true
|| (OR): either can be true

Like amusement park rules: height >= 120cm AND age >= 10
el.java_lesson1_ex11_comment2: Loop through names with variable name
el.java_lesson1_ex11_slide1_content:
Loops repeat actions automatically.

Instead of calling each name individually, loop says 'call everyone in order'!
el.java_lesson1_ex12_slide1_content:
HashMap stores key-value pairs, like a dictionary.

Look up 'apple' and get 'red fruit'!
el.java_lesson1_ex13_slide1_content:
Methods are reusable code blocks with names.

Like special moves in games - call the name and it executes!
el.java_lesson2_ex1_slide1_content:
Inheritance lets a child class inherit features from a parent class.

Like inheriting eye color from parents!
el.java_lesson2_ex2_slide1_content:
Override means rewriting a parent's method in the child class.

Animals make sounds, but dogs say 'Woof!' and cats say 'Meow!'
el.java_lesson2_ex3_slide1_content:
Interface defines methods a class must have - like a contract.

If you have a driver's license (implements), you can drive (have the method)!
el.java_lesson2_ex3_slide2_content:
A class can implement multiple interfaces.

Like having both a driver's license and a cooking license!
el.java_lesson2_ex4_slide1_content:
Abstract classes are incomplete blueprints that can't be instantiated directly.

'Animal' exists but you can't create a generic 'animal' - only specific ones like dogs or cats.
el.java_lesson2_ex5_comment2: Convert string to int with parseInt
el.java_lesson2_ex5_slide1_content:
Exceptions are unexpected problems during execution.

Like running out of sugar while cooking - can't follow the recipe!
el.java_lesson2_ex6_slide1_content:
finally always runs, whether exception occurs or not.

Like always cleaning up the kitchen after cooking, success or fail!
el.java_lesson2_ex7_slide1_content:
ArrayList is a resizable list.

Like an expandable bookshelf - add or remove books freely!
el.java_lesson2_ex7_slide2_content:
ArrayList<Integer> nums = new ArrayList<>();
nums.add(10);    // Add
nums.get(0);     // Get -> 10
nums.remove(0);  // Remove
nums.size();     // Size

Instead of calling each name individually, loop says 'call everyone in order'!
fi.java_lesson1_ex12_slide1_content:
HashMap stores key-value pairs, like a dictionary.

Look up 'apple' and get 'red fruit'!
fi.java_lesson1_ex13_slide1_content:
Methods are reusable code blocks with names.

Like special moves in games - call the name and it executes!
fi.java_lesson2_ex1_slide1_content:
Inheritance lets a child class inherit features from a parent class.

Like inheriting eye color from parents!
fi.java_lesson2_ex2_slide1_content:
Override means rewriting a parent's method in the child class.

Animals make sounds, but dogs say 'Woof!' and cats say 'Meow!'
fi.java_lesson2_ex3_slide1_content:
Interface defines methods a class must have - like a contract.

If you have a driver's license (implements), you can drive (have the method)!
fi.java_lesson2_ex3_slide2_content:
A class can implement multiple interfaces.

Like having both a driver's license and a cooking license!
fi.java_lesson2_ex4_slide1_content:
Abstract classes are incomplete blueprints that can't be instantiated directly.

'Animal' exists but you can't create a generic 'animal' - only specific ones like dogs or cats.
fi.java_lesson2_ex5_comment2: Convert string to int with parseInt
fi.java_lesson2_ex5_slide1_content:
Exceptions are unexpected problems during execution.

Like running out of sugar while cooking - can't follow the recipe!
fi.java_lesson2_ex6_slide1_content:
finally always runs, whether exception occurs or not.

Like always cleaning up the kitchen after cooking, success or fail!
fi.java_lesson2_ex7_slide1_content:
ArrayList is a resizable list.

Like an expandable bookshelf - add or remove books freely!
fi.java_lesson2_ex7_slide2_content:
ArrayList<Integer> nums = new ArrayList<>();
nums.add(10);    // Add
nums.get(0);     // Get -> 10
nums.remove(0);  // Remove
nums.size();     // Size
fi.java_lesson2_ex8_slide1_content:
Enhanced for easily processes all elements.

'Wash ALL fruits in this basket' - process everything in order!
fi.java_lesson2_ex9_slide1_content:
Static methods can be called without creating an instance.

Like a shared toolbox everyone can use!
fi.java_lesson2_ex10_slide1_content:
Access modifiers control who can access data.

public: Anyone can access
private: Only this class
protected: Child classes too
fi.java_lesson2_ex10_slide2_content:
Hide important data with private, access via methods.

Like bank accounts - can't change balance directly, must use deposit/withdraw!
fi.java_lesson3_ex1_slide1_content:
Lambda expressions write functions concisely.

x -> x * 2 means 'take x, return x times 2'
fi.java_lesson3_ex1_slide2_content:
() -> System.out.println("Hello")  // No params
x -> x * 2  // One param
(a, b) -> a + b  // Multiple params
fi.java_lesson3_ex2_slide1_content: Stream is an API for processing collection elements in sequence.
fi.java_lesson3_ex2_slide2_content:
list.stream()  // From collection
Arrays.stream(array)  // From array
Stream.of(1, 2, 3)  // From values
fi.java_lesson3_ex3_slide1_content:
map applies a function to each element.

nums.stream().map(n -> n * 2) doubles each number.
fi.java_lesson3_ex4_slide1_content:
filter keeps only elements matching a condition.

.filter(n -> n > 2) keeps numbers greater than 2.
fi.java_lesson3_ex5_slide1_content:
collect converts Stream results to a collection.

.collect(Collectors.toList()) creates a List.
fi.java_lesson3_ex5_slide2_content:
Collectors.toList()  // To List
Collectors.toSet()   // To Set
Collectors.joining(", ")  // Join strings
fi.java_lesson3_ex6_slide1_content:
reduce combines all elements into one value.

.reduce(0, (a, b) -> a + b) sums all numbers.
fi.java_lesson3_ex6_slide2_content:
.reduce(0, Integer::sum)  // Sum
.reduce(1, (a, b) -> a * b)  // Product
fi.java_lesson3_ex7_slide1_content:
Optional represents a value that may or may not exist.

Safely handle potentially null values!
fi.java_lesson3_ex7_slide2_content:
opt.orElse("default")  // Value or default
opt.ifPresent(System.out::println)  // If exists, process
fi.java_lesson3_ex8_slide1_content:
:: references existing methods as lambdas.

x -> System.out.println(x) becomes System.out::println
fi.java_lesson3_ex8_slide2_content:
Integer::parseInt  // Static method
System.out::println  // Instance method
String::length  // Any instance
ArrayList::new  // Constructor
fi.java_lesson3_ex9_slide1_content: sorted sorts elements in natural order.
fi.java_lesson4_ex1_slide1_content:
Generics let you specify types later.

Like a box that becomes 'String box' or 'Integer box' when you use it!
fi.java_lesson4_ex2_comment1: Limit type upper bound with extends
fi.java_lesson4_ex2_slide1_content:
extends limits which types are allowed.

<T extends Number> only accepts Number or its subclasses.
fi.java_lesson4_ex2_slide2_content:
NumBox<Integer> box = new NumBox<>();  // OK
NumBox<String> box2;  // Error! String isn't a Number
fi.java_lesson4_ex3_slide1_content:
? means 'any type' - like a joker card!

List<?> accepts List<String>, List<Integer>, etc.
fi.java_lesson4_ex3_slide2_content:
List<? extends Number>  // Number or subclass
List<? super Integer>   // Integer or superclass
fi.java_lesson4_ex4_slide1_content:
Map stores key-value pairs.

Like a phone book - look up name (key), get number (value)!
fi.java_lesson4_ex4_slide2_content:
containsKey("Alice")  // Check if key exists
getOrDefault("Bob", 0)  // Default if not found
keySet()  // All keys
values()  // All values
fi.java_lesson4_ex5_slide1_content:
entrySet gets all key-value pairs.

Like flipping through every page of a phone book!
fi.java_lesson4_ex6_comment1: Create list with new and asList
fi.java_lesson4_ex6_slide1_content:
Comparator defines how to sort.

Sort books by title, author, or year - you decide!
fi.java_lesson4_ex6_slide2_content:
Comparator.naturalOrder()  // Natural order
Comparator.reverseOrder()  // Reverse
Comparator.comparing(Person::getName)  // By property
fi.java_lesson4_ex7_slide1_content:
Implementing Comparable defines natural ordering for your class.

Like numbers having a natural order: 1 < 2 < 3
fi.java_lesson4_ex7_slide2_content:
this < other -> negative
this == other -> 0
this > other -> positive

return this.age - other.age;
fi.java_lesson4_ex8_slide1_content:
Enum defines a fixed set of constants.

Traffic lights: only RED, YELLOW, GREEN - nothing else!
fi.java_lesson4_ex9_slide1_content:
Queue is FIFO (First In, First Out).

Like a line at an amusement park - first in line rides first!
fi.java_lesson4_ex9_slide2_content:
offer(e)  // Add to end
poll()    // Remove from front (null if empty)
peek()    // Look at front (don't remove)
fi.java_lesson4_ex10_slide1_content:
Deque (Double-Ended Queue) allows operations at both ends.

Like a train with doors at both ends!
fi.java_lesson4_ex10_slide2_content:
Deque can be used as a LIFO stack.

stack.push(1);  // Push 1
stack.push(2);  // Push 2 (on top)
stack.pop();    // Pop 2 (top comes first)
fi.java_lesson5_ex1_slide1_content:
Exceptions are unexpected problems during execution.

Like breaking a plate while cooking!
fi.java_lesson5_ex2_slide1_content:
finally always executes, success or fail.

Always clean up the kitchen after cooking!
fi.java_lesson5_ex3_slide1_content:
throws declares that a method might throw an exception.

Warning label: 'This might explode, handle with care!'
fi.java_lesson5_ex3_slide2_content:
Caller must either catch or re-throw.

1. Catch it yourself
2. Pass it up with throws
fi.java_lesson5_ex4_slide1_content:
Create your own exception by extending Exception.

Like custom errors: 'Age cannot be negative!'
fi.java_lesson5_ex5_slide1_content:
try-with-resources automatically closes resources.

Like auto-return library books!
fi.java_lesson5_ex6_slide1_content:
BufferedReader reads text efficiently.

Reads line by line instead of character by character!
fi.java_lesson5_ex7_slide1_content:
BufferedWriter writes text efficiently.

Batches writes instead of one character at a time!
fi.java_lesson5_ex8_slide1_content:
Scanner parses text into words and numbers.

From '10 20 30', extract 10, 20, 30 as numbers!
fi.java_lesson5_ex8_slide2_content:
nextInt()    // Read integer
nextDouble() // Read decimal
next()       // Read word
nextLine()   // Read line
fi.java_lesson5_ex9_slide1_content:
Java 7's Files class makes file operations easy.

Like automatic doors - easier than manual!
fi.java_lesson5_ex9_slide2_content:
Files.readAllLines(path)  // Read all lines
Files.readString(path)    // Read as string
Files.write(path, lines)  // Write
Files.exists(path)        // Check existence
fi.java_lesson5_ex10_slide1_content:
Use | to catch multiple exception types together.

'If apple OR orange falls, catch it!'

fr.java_lesson1_course_description: Learn the basics of Java, a strict but reliable language. Master the rules to give computers precise instructions.
fr.java_lesson2_course_description: After mastering basics, dive into object-oriented programming! Learn inheritance, interfaces, and exception handling.
fr.java_lesson3_course_description: Learn Java 8+ features. Stream API, lambda expressions, Optional - master modern Java.
fr.java_lesson4_course_description: Learn advanced generics and collections. Write type-safe code with important concepts.
fr.java_lesson5_course_description: Learn exception handling and file I/O. Essential skills for robust programs.
fr.java_lesson1_ex1_slide1_content:
Java is a reliable programming language used worldwide in banks and Android apps.

Think of Java as a strict teacher - rules are tough, but they help you write safe programs with fewer mistakes.
fr.java_lesson1_ex2_slide1_content:
Variables are like labeled drawers that store data.

Just like 'snack drawer' or 'toy drawer', give your variables meaningful names!
fr.java_lesson1_ex3_slide1_content:
Use int (integer) for whole numbers.

Rules:
- Text -> String
- Numbers -> int
fr.java_lesson1_ex4_slide1_content:
% gives the remainder of division.

Example: 10 candies shared by 3 people = 3 each, 1 remains!
fr.java_lesson1_ex6_slide1_content:
Concatenation joins text and variables using +.

Like connecting puzzle pieces!
fr.java_lesson1_ex7_slide1_content:
Arrays are like numbered lockers that hold data in order.

Great for shopping lists or class rosters!
fr.java_lesson1_ex8_slide1_content:
Make decisions based on conditions.

Like a fork in the road - if score >= 80, pass; otherwise, fail.
fr.java_lesson1_ex9_slide1_content:
else handles the alternative case.

If sunny, play outside; otherwise, play games inside.
fr.java_lesson1_ex10_slide1_content:
&& (AND): both must be true
|| (OR): either can be true

Like amusement park rules: height >= 120cm AND age >= 10

it.java_lesson1_course_description: Learn the basics of Java, a strict but reliable language. Master the rules to give computers precise instructions.
it.java_lesson2_course_description: After mastering basics, dive into object-oriented programming! Learn inheritance, interfaces, and exception handling.
it.java_lesson3_course_description: Learn Java 8+ features. Stream API, lambda expressions, Optional - master modern Java.
it.java_lesson4_course_description: Learn advanced generics and collections. Write type-safe code with important concepts.
it.java_lesson5_course_description: Learn exception handling and file I/O. Essential skills for robust programs.
it.java_lesson1_ex1_slide1_content:
Java is a reliable programming language used worldwide in banks and Android apps.

Think of Java as a strict teacher - rules are tough, but they help you write safe programs with fewer mistakes.
it.java_lesson1_ex2_slide1_content:
Variables are like labeled drawers that store data.

Just like 'snack drawer' or 'toy drawer', give your variables meaningful names!
it.java_lesson1_ex3_slide1_content:
Use int (integer) for whole numbers.

Rules:
- Text -> String
- Numbers -> int
it.java_lesson1_ex4_slide1_content:
% gives the remainder of division.

Example: 10 candies shared by 3 people = 3 each, 1 remains!
it.java_lesson1_ex6_slide1_content:
Concatenation joins text and variables using +.

Like connecting puzzle pieces!
it.java_lesson1_ex7_slide1_content:
Arrays are like numbered lockers that hold data in order.

Great for shopping lists or class rosters!
it.java_lesson1_ex8_slide1_content:
Make decisions based on conditions.

Like a fork in the road - if score >= 80, pass; otherwise, fail.
it.java_lesson1_ex9_slide1_content:
else handles the alternative case.

If sunny, play outside; otherwise, play games inside.
it.java_lesson1_ex10_slide1_content:
&& (AND): both must be true
|| (OR): either can be true

Like amusement park rules: height >= 120cm AND age >= 10
it.java_lesson1_ex11_comment2: Loop through names with variable name
it.java_lesson1_ex11_slide1_content:
Loops repeat actions automatically.

Instead of calling each name individually, loop says 'call everyone in order'!
it.java_lesson1_ex12_slide1_content:
HashMap stores key-value pairs, like a dictionary.

Look up 'apple' and get 'red fruit'!
it.java_lesson1_ex13_slide1_content:
Methods are reusable code blocks with names.

Like special moves in games - call the name and it executes!
it.java_lesson2_ex1_slide1_content:
Inheritance lets a child class inherit features from a parent class.

Like inheriting eye color from parents!
it.java_lesson2_ex2_slide1_content:
Override means rewriting a parent's method in the child class.

Animals make sounds, but dogs say 'Woof!' and cats say 'Meow!'
it.java_lesson2_ex3_slide1_content:
Interface defines methods a class must have - like a contract.

If you have a driver's license (implements), you can drive (have the method)!
it.java_lesson2_ex3_slide2_content:
A class can implement multiple interfaces.

Like having both a driver's license and a cooking license!
it.java_lesson2_ex4_slide1_content:
Abstract classes are incomplete blueprints that can't be instantiated directly.

'Animal' exists but you can't create a generic 'animal' - only specific ones like dogs or cats.
it.java_lesson2_ex5_comment2: Convert string to int with parseInt
it.java_lesson2_ex5_slide1_content:
Exceptions are unexpected problems during execution.

Like running out of sugar while cooking - can't follow the recipe!
it.java_lesson2_ex6_slide1_content:
finally always runs, whether exception occurs or not.

Like always cleaning up the kitchen after cooking, success or fail!
it.java_lesson2_ex7_slide1_content:
ArrayList is a resizable list.

Like an expandable bookshelf - add or remove books freely!
it.java_lesson2_ex7_slide2_content:
ArrayList<Integer> nums = new ArrayList<>();
nums.add(10);    // Add
nums.get(0);     // Get -> 10
nums.remove(0);  // Remove
nums.size();     // Size
it.java_lesson2_ex8_slide1_content:
Enhanced for easily processes all elements.

'Wash ALL fruits in this basket' - process everything in order!
it.java_lesson2_ex9_slide1_content:
Static methods can be called without creating an instance.

Like a shared toolbox everyone can use!
it.java_lesson2_ex10_slide1_content:
Access modifiers control who can access data.

public: Anyone can access
private: Only this class
protected: Child classes too
it.java_lesson2_ex10_slide2_content:
Hide important data with private, access via methods.

Like bank accounts - can't change balance directly, must use deposit/withdraw!
it.java_lesson3_ex1_slide1_content:
Lambda expressions write functions concisely.

x -> x * 2 means 'take x, return x times 2'
it.java_lesson3_ex1_slide2_content:
() -> System.out.println("Hello")  // No params
x -> x * 2  // One param
(a, b) -> a + b  // Multiple params
it.java_lesson3_ex2_slide1_content: Stream is an API for processing collection elements in sequence.
it.java_lesson3_ex2_slide2_content:
list.stream()  // From collection
Arrays.stream(array)  // From array
Stream.of(1, 2, 3)  // From values
it.java_lesson3_ex3_slide1_content:
map applies a function to each element.

nums.stream().map(n -> n * 2) doubles each number.
it.java_lesson3_ex4_slide1_content:
filter keeps only elements matching a condition.

.filter(n -> n > 2) keeps numbers greater than 2.
it.java_lesson3_ex5_slide1_content:
collect converts Stream results to a collection.

.collect(Collectors.toList()) creates a List.
it.java_lesson3_ex5_slide2_content:
Collectors.toList()  // To List
Collectors.toSet()   // To Set
Collectors.joining(", ")  // Join strings
it.java_lesson3_ex6_slide1_content:
reduce combines all elements into one value.

.reduce(0, (a, b) -> a + b) sums all numbers.
it.java_lesson3_ex6_slide2_content:
.reduce(0, Integer::sum)  // Sum
.reduce(1, (a, b) -> a * b)  // Product
it.java_lesson3_ex7_slide1_content:
Optional represents a value that may or may not exist.

Safely handle potentially null values!
it.java_lesson3_ex7_slide2_content:
opt.orElse("default")  // Value or default
opt.ifPresent(System.out::println)  // If exists, process
it.java_lesson3_ex8_slide1_content:
:: references existing methods as lambdas.

x -> System.out.println(x) becomes System.out::println
it.java_lesson3_ex8_slide2_content:
Integer::parseInt  // Static method
System.out::println  // Instance method
String::length  // Any instance
ArrayList::new  // Constructor
it.java_lesson3_ex9_slide1_content: sorted sorts elements in natural order.
it.java_lesson4_ex1_slide1_content:
Generics let you specify types later.

Like a box that becomes 'String box' or 'Integer box' when you use it!
it.java_lesson4_ex2_comment1: Limit type upper bound with extends
it.java_lesson4_ex2_slide1_content:
extends limits which types are allowed.

<T extends Number> only accepts Number or its subclasses.
it.java_lesson4_ex2_slide2_content:
NumBox<Integer> box = new NumBox<>();  // OK
NumBox<String> box2;  // Error! String isn't a Number
it.java_lesson4_ex3_slide1_content:
? means 'any type' - like a joker card!

List<?> accepts List<String>, List<Integer>, etc.
it.java_lesson4_ex3_slide2_content:
List<? extends Number>  // Number or subclass
List<? super Integer>   // Integer or superclass
it.java_lesson4_ex4_slide1_content:
Map stores key-value pairs.

Like a phone book - look up name (key), get number (value)!
it.java_lesson4_ex4_slide2_content:
containsKey("Alice")  // Check if key exists
getOrDefault("Bob", 0)  // Default if not found
keySet()  // All keys
values()  // All values
it.java_lesson4_ex5_slide1_content:
entrySet gets all key-value pairs.

Like flipping through every page of a phone book!
it.java_lesson4_ex6_comment1: Create list with new and asList
it.java_lesson4_ex6_slide1_content:
Comparator defines how to sort.

Sort books by title, author, or year - you decide!
it.java_lesson4_ex6_slide2_content:
Comparator.naturalOrder()  // Natural order
Comparator.reverseOrder()  // Reverse
Comparator.comparing(Person::getName)  // By property
it.java_lesson4_ex7_slide1_content:
Implementing Comparable defines natural ordering for your class.

Like numbers having a natural order: 1 < 2 < 3
it.java_lesson4_ex7_slide2_content:
this < other -> negative
this == other -> 0
this > other -> positive

return this.age - other.age;
it.java_lesson4_ex8_slide1_content:
Enum defines a fixed set of constants.

Traffic lights: only RED, YELLOW, GREEN - nothing else!
it.java_lesson4_ex9_slide1_content:
Queue is FIFO (First In, First Out).

Like a line at an amusement park - first in line rides first!
it.java_lesson4_ex9_slide2_content:
offer(e)  // Add to end
poll()    // Remove from front (null if empty)
peek()    // Look at front (don't remove)
it.java_lesson4_ex10_slide1_content:
Deque (Double-Ended Queue) allows operations at both ends.

Like a train with doors at both ends!
it.java_lesson4_ex10_slide2_content:
Deque can be used as a LIFO stack.

stack.push(1);  // Push 1
stack.push(2);  // Push 2 (on top)
stack.pop();    // Pop 2 (top comes first)
it.java_lesson5_ex1_slide1_content:
Exceptions are unexpected problems during execution.

Like breaking a plate while cooking!
it.java_lesson5_ex2_slide1_content:
finally always executes, success or fail.

Always clean up the kitchen after cooking!
it.java_lesson5_ex3_slide1_content:
throws declares that a method might throw an exception.

Warning label: 'This might explode, handle with care!'
it.java_lesson5_ex3_slide2_content:
Caller must either catch or re-throw.

1. Catch it yourself
2. Pass it up with throws
it.java_lesson5_ex4_slide1_content:
Create your own exception by extending Exception.

Like custom errors: 'Age cannot be negative!'
it.java_lesson5_ex5_slide1_content:
try-with-resources automatically closes resources.

Like auto-return library books!
it.java_lesson5_ex6_slide1_content:
BufferedReader reads text efficiently.

Reads line by line instead of character by character!
it.java_lesson5_ex7_slide1_content:
BufferedWriter writes text efficiently.

Batches writes instead of one character at a time!
it.java_lesson5_ex8_slide1_content:
Scanner parses text into words and numbers.

From '10 20 30', extract 10, 20, 30 as numbers!
it.java_lesson5_ex8_slide2_content:
nextInt()    // Read integer
nextDouble() // Read decimal
next()       // Read word
nextLine()   // Read line
it.java_lesson5_ex9_slide1_content:
Java 7's Files class makes file operations easy.

Like automatic doors - easier than manual!
it.java_lesson5_ex9_slide2_content:
Files.readAllLines(path)  // Read all lines
Files.readString(path)    // Read as string
Files.write(path, lines)  // Write
Files.exists(path)        // Check existence
it.java_lesson5_ex10_slide1_content:
Use | to catch multiple exception types together.

'If apple OR orange falls, catch it!'

no.java_lesson1_course_description: Learn the basics of Java, a strict but reliable language. Master the rules to give computers precise instructions.
no.java_lesson2_course_description: After mastering basics, dive into object-oriented programming! Learn inheritance, interfaces, and exception handling.
no.java_lesson3_course_description: Learn Java 8+ features. Stream API, lambda expressions, Optional - master modern Java.
no.java_lesson4_course_description: Learn advanced generics and collections. Write type-safe code with important concepts.
no.java_lesson5_course_description: Learn exception handling and file I/O. Essential skills for robust programs.
no.java_lesson1_ex1_slide1_content:
Java is a reliable programming language used worldwide in banks and Android apps.

Think of Java as a strict teacher - rules are tough, but they help you write safe programs with fewer mistakes.
no.java_lesson1_ex2_slide1_content:
Variables are like labeled drawers that store data.

Just like 'snack drawer' or 'toy drawer', give your variables meaningful names!
no.java_lesson1_ex3_slide1_content:
Use int (integer) for whole numbers.

Rules:
- Text -> String
- Numbers -> int
no.java_lesson1_ex4_slide1_content:
% gives the remainder of division.

Example: 10 candies shared by 3 people = 3 each, 1 remains!
no.java_lesson1_ex6_slide1_content:
Concatenation joins text and variables using +.

Like connecting puzzle pieces!
no.java_lesson1_ex7_slide1_content:
Arrays are like numbered lockers that hold data in order.

Great for shopping lists or class rosters!
no.java_lesson1_ex8_slide1_content:
Make decisions based on conditions.

Like a fork in the road - if score >= 80, pass; otherwise, fail.
no.java_lesson1_ex9_slide1_content:
else handles the alternative case.

If sunny, play outside; otherwise, play games inside.
no.java_lesson1_ex10_slide1_content:
&& (AND): both must be true
|| (OR): either can be true

Like amusement park rules: height >= 120cm AND age >= 10
no.java_lesson1_ex11_comment2: Loop through names with variable name
no.java_lesson1_ex11_slide1_content:
Loops repeat actions automatically.

Instead of calling each name individually, loop says 'call everyone in order'!
no.java_lesson1_ex12_slide1_content:
HashMap stores key-value pairs, like a dictionary.

Look up 'apple' and get 'red fruit'!
no.java_lesson1_ex13_slide1_content:
Methods are reusable code blocks with names.

Like special moves in games - call the name and it executes!
no.java_lesson2_ex1_slide1_content:
Inheritance lets a child class inherit features from a parent class.

Like inheriting eye color from parents!
no.java_lesson2_ex2_slide1_content:
Override means rewriting a parent's method in the child class.

Animals make sounds, but dogs say 'Woof!' and cats say 'Meow!'
no.java_lesson2_ex3_slide1_content:
Interface defines methods a class must have - like a contract.

If you have a driver's license (implements), you can drive (have the method)!
no.java_lesson2_ex3_slide2_content:
A class can implement multiple interfaces.

Like having both a driver's license and a cooking license!
no.java_lesson2_ex4_slide1_content:
Abstract classes are incomplete blueprints that can't be instantiated directly.

'Animal' exists but you can't create a generic 'animal' - only specific ones like dogs or cats.
no.java_lesson2_ex5_comment2: Convert string to int with parseInt
no.java_lesson2_ex5_slide1_content:
Exceptions are unexpected problems during execution.

Like running out of sugar while cooking - can't follow the recipe!
no.java_lesson2_ex6_slide1_content:
finally always runs, whether exception occurs or not.

Like always cleaning up the kitchen after cooking, success or fail!
no.java_lesson2_ex7_slide1_content:
ArrayList is a resizable list.

Like an expandable bookshelf - add or remove books freely!
no.java_lesson2_ex7_slide2_content:
ArrayList<Integer> nums = new ArrayList<>();
nums.add(10);    // Add
nums.get(0);     // Get -> 10
nums.remove(0);  // Remove
nums.size();     // Size
no.java_lesson2_ex8_slide1_content:
Enhanced for easily processes all elements.

'Wash ALL fruits in this basket' - process everything in order!
no.java_lesson2_ex9_slide1_content:
Static methods can be called without creating an instance.

Like a shared toolbox everyone can use!
no.java_lesson2_ex10_slide1_content:
Access modifiers control who can access data.

public: Anyone can access
private: Only this class
protected: Child classes too
no.java_lesson2_ex10_slide2_content:
Hide important data with private, access via methods.

Like bank accounts - can't change balance directly, must use deposit/withdraw!
no.java_lesson3_ex1_slide1_content:
Lambda expressions write functions concisely.

x -> x * 2 means 'take x, return x times 2'
no.java_lesson3_ex1_slide2_content:
() -> System.out.println("Hello")  // No params
x -> x * 2  // One param
(a, b) -> a + b  // Multiple params
no.java_lesson3_ex2_slide1_content: Stream is an API for processing collection elements in sequence.
no.java_lesson3_ex2_slide2_content:
list.stream()  // From collection
Arrays.stream(array)  // From array
Stream.of(1, 2, 3)  // From values
no.java_lesson3_ex3_slide1_content:
map applies a function to each element.

nums.stream().map(n -> n * 2) doubles each number.
no.java_lesson3_ex4_slide1_content:
filter keeps only elements matching a condition.

.filter(n -> n > 2) keeps numbers greater than 2.
no.java_lesson3_ex5_slide1_content:
collect converts Stream results to a collection.

.collect(Collectors.toList()) creates a List.
no.java_lesson3_ex5_slide2_content:
Collectors.toList()  // To List
Collectors.toSet()   // To Set
Collectors.joining(", ")  // Join strings
no.java_lesson3_ex6_slide1_content:
reduce combines all elements into one value.

.reduce(0, (a, b) -> a + b) sums all numbers.
no.java_lesson3_ex6_slide2_content:
.reduce(0, Integer::sum)  // Sum
.reduce(1, (a, b) -> a * b)  // Product
no.java_lesson3_ex7_slide1_content:
Optional represents a value that may or may not exist.

Safely handle potentially null values!
no.java_lesson3_ex7_slide2_content:
opt.orElse("default")  // Value or default
opt.ifPresent(System.out::println)  // If exists, process
no.java_lesson3_ex8_slide1_content:
:: references existing methods as lambdas.

x -> System.out.println(x) becomes System.out::println
no.java_lesson3_ex8_slide2_content:
Integer::parseInt  // Static method
System.out::println  // Instance method
String::length  // Any instance
ArrayList::new  // Constructor
no.java_lesson3_ex9_slide1_content: sorted sorts elements in natural order.
no.java_lesson4_ex1_slide1_content:
Generics let you specify types later.

Like a box that becomes 'String box' or 'Integer box' when you use it!
no.java_lesson4_ex2_comment1: Limit type upper bound with extends
no.java_lesson4_ex2_slide1_content:
extends limits which types are allowed.

<T extends Number> only accepts Number or its subclasses.
no.java_lesson4_ex2_slide2_content:
NumBox<Integer> box = new NumBox<>();  // OK
NumBox<String> box2;  // Error! String isn't a Number
no.java_lesson4_ex3_slide1_content:
? means 'any type' - like a joker card!

List<?> accepts List<String>, List<Integer>, etc.
no.java_lesson4_ex3_slide2_content:
List<? extends Number>  // Number or subclass
List<? super Integer>   // Integer or superclass
no.java_lesson4_ex4_slide1_content:
Map stores key-value pairs.

Like a phone book - look up name (key), get number (value)!
no.java_lesson4_ex4_slide2_content:
containsKey("Alice")  // Check if key exists
getOrDefault("Bob", 0)  // Default if not found
keySet()  // All keys
values()  // All values
no.java_lesson4_ex5_slide1_content:
entrySet gets all key-value pairs.

Like flipping through every page of a phone book!
no.java_lesson4_ex6_comment1: Create list with new and asList
no.java_lesson4_ex6_slide1_content:
Comparator defines how to sort.

Sort books by title, author, or year - you decide!
no.java_lesson4_ex6_slide2_content:
Comparator.naturalOrder()  // Natural order
Comparator.reverseOrder()  // Reverse
Comparator.comparing(Person::getName)  // By property
no.java_lesson4_ex7_slide1_content:
Implementing Comparable defines natural ordering for your class.

Like numbers having a natural order: 1 < 2 < 3
no.java_lesson4_ex7_slide2_content:
this < other -> negative
this == other -> 0
this > other -> positive

return this.age - other.age;
no.java_lesson4_ex8_slide1_content:
Enum defines a fixed set of constants.

Traffic lights: only RED, YELLOW, GREEN - nothing else!
no.java_lesson4_ex9_slide1_content:
Queue is FIFO (First In, First Out).

Like a line at an amusement park - first in line rides first!
no.java_lesson4_ex9_slide2_content:
offer(e)  // Add to end
poll()    // Remove from front (null if empty)
peek()    // Look at front (don't remove)
no.java_lesson4_ex10_slide1_content:
Deque (Double-Ended Queue) allows operations at both ends.

Like a train with doors at both ends!
no.java_lesson4_ex10_slide2_content:
Deque can be used as a LIFO stack.

stack.push(1);  // Push 1
stack.push(2);  // Push 2 (on top)
stack.pop();    // Pop 2 (top comes first)
no.java_lesson5_ex1_slide1_content:
Exceptions are unexpected problems during execution.

Like breaking a plate while cooking!
no.java_lesson5_ex2_slide1_content:
finally always executes, success or fail.

Always clean up the kitchen after cooking!
no.java_lesson5_ex3_slide1_content:
throws declares that a method might throw an exception.

Warning label: 'This might explode, handle with care!'
no.java_lesson5_ex3_slide2_content:
Caller must either catch or re-throw.

1. Catch it yourself
2. Pass it up with throws
no.java_lesson5_ex4_slide1_content:
Create your own exception by extending Exception.

Like custom errors: 'Age cannot be negative!'
no.java_lesson5_ex5_slide1_content:
try-with-resources automatically closes resources.

Like auto-return library books!
no.java_lesson5_ex6_slide1_content:
BufferedReader reads text efficiently.

Reads line by line instead of character by character!
no.java_lesson5_ex7_slide1_content:
BufferedWriter writes text efficiently.

Batches writes instead of one character at a time!
no.java_lesson5_ex8_slide1_content:
Scanner parses text into words and numbers.

From '10 20 30', extract 10, 20, 30 as numbers!
no.java_lesson5_ex8_slide2_content:
nextInt()    // Read integer
nextDouble() // Read decimal
next()       // Read word
nextLine()   // Read line
no.java_lesson5_ex9_slide1_content:
Java 7's Files class makes file operations easy.

Like automatic doors - easier than manual!
no.java_lesson5_ex9_slide2_content:
Files.readAllLines(path)  // Read all lines
Files.readString(path)    // Read as string
Files.write(path, lines)  // Write
Files.exists(path)        // Check existence
no.java_lesson5_ex10_slide1_content:
Use | to catch multiple exception types together.

'If apple OR orange falls, catch it!'
