pt.java_lesson1_course_description: Learn the basics of Java, a strict but reliable language. Master the rules to give computers precise instructions.
pt.java_lesson2_course_description: After mastering basics, dive into object-oriented programming! Learn inheritance, interfaces, and exception handling.
pt.java_lesson3_course_description: Learn Java 8+ features. Stream API, lambda expressions, Optional - master modern Java.
pt.java_lesson4_course_description: Learn advanced generics and collections. Write type-safe code with important concepts.
pt.java_lesson5_course_description: Learn exception handling and file I/O. Essential skills for robust programs.
pt.java_lesson1_ex1_slide1_content:
Java is a reliable programming language used worldwide in banks and Android apps.

Think of Java as a strict teacher - rules are tough, but they help you write safe programs with fewer mistakes.
pt.java_lesson1_ex2_slide1_content:
Variables are like labeled drawers that store data.

Just like 'snack drawer' or 'toy drawer', give your variables meaningful names!
pt.java_lesson1_ex3_slide1_content:
Use int (integer) for whole numbers.

Rules:
- Text -> String
- Numbers -> int
pt.java_lesson1_ex4_slide1_content:
% gives the remainder of division.

Example: 10 candies shared by 3 people = 3 each, 1 remains!
pt.java_lesson1_ex6_slide1_content:
Concatenation joins text and variables using +.

Like connecting puzzle pieces!
pt.java_lesson1_ex7_slide1_content:
Arrays are like numbered lockers that hold data in order.

Great for shopping lists or class rosters!
pt.java_lesson1_ex8_slide1_content:
Make decisions based on conditions.

Like a fork in the road - if score >= 80, pass; otherwise, fail.
pt.java_lesson1_ex9_slide1_content:
else handles the alternative case.

If sunny, play outside; otherwise, play games inside.
pt.java_lesson1_ex10_slide1_content:
&& (AND): both must be true
|| (OR): either can be true

Like amusement park rules: height >= 120cm AND age >= 10
pt.java_lesson1_ex11_comment2: Loop through names with variable name
pt.java_lesson1_ex11_slide1_content:
Loops repeat actions automatically.

Instead of calling each name individually, loop says 'call everyone in order'!
pt.java_lesson1_ex12_slide1_content:
HashMap stores key-value pairs, like a dictionary.

Look up 'apple' and get 'red fruit'!
pt.java_lesson1_ex13_slide1_content:
Methods are reusable code blocks with names.

Like special moves in games - call the name and it executes!
pt.java_lesson2_ex1_slide1_content:
Inheritance lets a child class inherit features from a parent class.

Like inheriting eye color from parents!
pt.java_lesson2_ex2_slide1_content:
Override means rewriting a parent's method in the child class.

Animals make sounds, but dogs say 'Woof!' and cats say 'Meow!'
pt.java_lesson2_ex3_slide1_content:
Interface defines methods a class must have - like a contract.

If you have a driver's license (implements), you can drive (have the method)!
pt.java_lesson2_ex3_slide2_content:
A class can implement multiple interfaces.

Like having both a driver's license and a cooking license!
pt.java_lesson2_ex4_slide1_content:
Abstract classes are incomplete blueprints that can't be instantiated directly.

'Animal' exists but you can't create a generic 'animal' - only specific ones like dogs or cats.
pt.java_lesson2_ex5_comment2: Convert string to int with parseInt
pt.java_lesson2_ex5_slide1_content:
Exceptions are unexpected problems during execution.

Like running out of sugar while cooking - can't follow the recipe!
pt.java_lesson2_ex6_slide1_content:
finally always runs, whether exception occurs or not.

Like always cleaning up the kitchen after cooking, success or fail!
pt.java_lesson2_ex7_slide1_content:
ArrayList is a resizable list.

Like an expandable bookshelf - add or remove books freely!
pt.java_lesson2_ex7_slide2_content:
ArrayList<Integer> nums = new ArrayList<>();
nums.add(10);    // Add
nums.get(0);     // Get -> 10
nums.remove(0);  // Remove
nums.size();     // Size
pt.java_lesson2_ex8_slide1_content:
Enhanced for easily processes all elements.

'Wash ALL fruits in this basket' - process everything in order!
pt.java_lesson2_ex9_slide1_content:
Static methods can be called without creating an instance.

Like a shared toolbox everyone can use!
pt.java_lesson2_ex10_slide1_content:
Access modifiers control who can access data.

public: Anyone can access
private: Only this class
protected: Child classes too
pt.java_lesson2_ex10_slide2_content:
Hide important data with private, access via methods.

Like bank accounts - can't change balance directly, must use deposit/withdraw!
pt.java_lesson3_ex1_slide1_content:
Lambda expressions write functions concisely.

x -> x * 2 means 'take x, return x times 2'
pt.java_lesson3_ex1_slide2_content:
() -> System.out.println("Hello")  // No params
x -> x * 2  // One param
(a, b) -> a + b  // Multiple params
pt.java_lesson3_ex2_slide1_content: Stream is an API for processing collection elements in sequence.
pt.java_lesson3_ex2_slide2_content:
list.stream()  // From collection
Arrays.stream(array)  // From array
Stream.of(1, 2, 3)  // From values
pt.java_lesson3_ex3_slide1_content:
map applies a function to each element.

nums.stream().map(n -> n * 2) doubles each number.
pt.java_lesson3_ex4_slide1_content:
filter keeps only elements matching a condition.

.filter(n -> n > 2) keeps numbers greater than 2.
pt.java_lesson3_ex5_slide1_content:
collect converts Stream results to a collection.

.collect(Collectors.toList()) creates a List.
pt.java_lesson3_ex5_slide2_content:
Collectors.toList()  // To List
Collectors.toSet()   // To Set
Collectors.joining(", ")  // Join strings
pt.java_lesson3_ex6_slide1_content:
reduce combines all elements into one value.

.reduce(0, (a, b) -> a + b) sums all numbers.
pt.java_lesson3_ex6_slide2_content:
.reduce(0, Integer::sum)  // Sum
.reduce(1, (a, b) -> a * b)  // Product
pt.java_lesson3_ex7_slide1_content:
Optional represents a value that may or may not exist.

Safely handle potentially null values!
pt.java_lesson3_ex7_slide2_content:
opt.orElse("default")  // Value or default
opt.ifPresent(System.out::println)  // If exists, process
pt.java_lesson3_ex8_slide1_content:
:: references existing methods as lambdas.

x -> System.out.println(x) becomes System.out::println
pt.java_lesson3_ex8_slide2_content:
Integer::parseInt  // Static method
System.out::println  // Instance method
String::length  // Any instance
ArrayList::new  // Constructor
pt.java_lesson3_ex9_slide1_content: sorted sorts elements in natural order.
pt.java_lesson4_ex1_slide1_content:
Generics let you specify types later.

Like a box that becomes 'String box' or 'Integer box' when you use it!
pt.java_lesson4_ex2_comment1: Limit type upper bound with extends
pt.java_lesson4_ex2_slide1_content:
extends limits which types are allowed.

<T extends Number> only accepts Number or its subclasses.
pt.java_lesson4_ex2_slide2_content:
NumBox<Integer> box = new NumBox<>();  // OK
NumBox<String> box2;  // Error! String isn't a Number
pt.java_lesson4_ex3_slide1_content:
? means 'any type' - like a joker card!

List<?> accepts List<String>, List<Integer>, etc.
pt.java_lesson4_ex3_slide2_content:
List<? extends Number>  // Number or subclass
List<? super Integer>   // Integer or superclass
pt.java_lesson4_ex4_slide1_content:
Map stores key-value pairs.

Like a phone book - look up name (key), get number (value)!
pt.java_lesson4_ex4_slide2_content:
containsKey("Alice")  // Check if key exists
getOrDefault("Bob", 0)  // Default if not found
keySet()  // All keys
values()  // All values
pt.java_lesson4_ex5_slide1_content:
entrySet gets all key-value pairs.

Like flipping through every page of a phone book!
pt.java_lesson4_ex6_comment1: Create list with new and asList
pt.java_lesson4_ex6_slide1_content:
Comparator defines how to sort.

Sort books by title, author, or year - you decide!
pt.java_lesson4_ex6_slide2_content:
Comparator.naturalOrder()  // Natural order
Comparator.reverseOrder()  // Reverse
Comparator.comparing(Person::getName)  // By property
pt.java_lesson4_ex7_slide1_content:
Implementing Comparable defines natural ordering for your class.

Like numbers having a natural order: 1 < 2 < 3
pt.java_lesson4_ex7_slide2_content:
this < other -> negative
this == other -> 0
this > other -> positive

return this.age - other.age;
pt.java_lesson4_ex8_slide1_content:
Enum defines a fixed set of constants.

Traffic lights: only RED, YELLOW, GREEN - nothing else!
pt.java_lesson4_ex9_slide1_content:
Queue is FIFO (First In, First Out).

Like a line at an amusement park - first in line rides first!
pt.java_lesson4_ex9_slide2_content:
offer(e)  // Add to end
poll()    // Remove from front (null if empty)
peek()    // Look at front (don't remove)
pt.java_lesson4_ex10_slide1_content:
Deque (Double-Ended Queue) allows operations at both ends.

Like a train with doors at both ends!
pt.java_lesson4_ex10_slide2_content:
Deque can be used as a LIFO stack.

stack.push(1);  // Push 1
stack.push(2);  // Push 2 (on top)
stack.pop();    // Pop 2 (top comes first)
pt.java_lesson5_ex1_slide1_content:
Exceptions are unexpected problems during execution.

Like breaking a plate while cooking!
pt.java_lesson5_ex2_slide1_content:
finally always executes, success or fail.

Always clean up the kitchen after cooking!
pt.java_lesson5_ex3_slide1_content:
throws declares that a method might throw an exception.

Warning label: 'This might explode, handle with care!'
pt.java_lesson5_ex3_slide2_content:
Caller must either catch or re-throw.

1. Catch it yourself
2. Pass it up with throws
pt.java_lesson5_ex4_slide1_content:
Create your own exception by extending Exception.

Like custom errors: 'Age cannot be negative!'
pt.java_lesson5_ex5_slide1_content:
try-with-resources automatically closes resources.

Like auto-return library books!
pt.java_lesson5_ex6_slide1_content:
BufferedReader reads text efficiently.

Reads line by line instead of character by character!
pt.java_lesson5_ex7_slide1_content:
BufferedWriter writes text efficiently.

Batches writes instead of one character at a time!
pt.java_lesson5_ex8_slide1_content:
Scanner parses text into words and numbers.

From '10 20 30', extract 10, 20, 30 as numbers!
pt.java_lesson5_ex8_slide2_content:
nextInt()    // Read integer
nextDouble() // Read decimal
next()       // Read word
nextLine()   // Read line
pt.java_lesson5_ex9_slide1_content:
Java 7's Files class makes file operations easy.

Like automatic doors - easier than manual!
pt.java_lesson5_ex9_slide2_content:
Files.readAllLines(path)  // Read all lines
Files.readString(path)    // Read as string
Files.write(path, lines)  // Write
Files.exists(path)        // Check existence
pt.java_lesson5_ex10_slide1_content:
Use | to catch multiple exception types together.

'If apple OR orange falls, catch it!'

Sort books by title, author, or year - you decide!
ro.java_lesson4_ex6_slide2_content:
Comparator.naturalOrder()  // Natural order
Comparator.reverseOrder()  // Reverse
Comparator.comparing(Person::getName)  // By property
ro.java_lesson4_ex7_slide1_content:
Implementing Comparable defines natural ordering for your class.

Like numbers having a natural order: 1 < 2 < 3
ro.java_lesson4_ex7_slide2_content:
this < other -> negative
this == other -> 0
this > other -> positive

return this.age - other.age;
ro.java_lesson4_ex8_slide1_content:
Enum defines a fixed set of constants.

Traffic lights: only RED, YELLOW, GREEN - nothing else!
ro.java_lesson4_ex9_slide1_content:
Queue is FIFO (First In, First Out).

Like a line at an amusement park - first in line rides first!
ro.java_lesson4_ex9_slide2_content:
offer(e)  // Add to end
poll()    // Remove from front (null if empty)
peek()    // Look at front (don't remove)
ro.java_lesson4_ex10_slide1_content:
Deque (Double-Ended Queue) allows operations at both ends.

Like a train with doors at both ends!
ro.java_lesson4_ex10_slide2_content:
Deque can be used as a LIFO stack.

stack.push(1);  // Push 1
stack.push(2);  // Push 2 (on top)
stack.pop();    // Pop 2 (top comes first)
ro.java_lesson5_ex1_slide1_content:
Exceptions are unexpected problems during execution.

Like breaking a plate while cooking!
ro.java_lesson5_ex2_slide1_content:
finally always executes, success or fail.

Always clean up the kitchen after cooking!
ro.java_lesson5_ex3_slide1_content:
throws declares that a method might throw an exception.

Warning label: 'This might explode, handle with care!'
ro.java_lesson5_ex3_slide2_content:
Caller must either catch or re-throw.

1. Catch it yourself
2. Pass it up with throws
ro.java_lesson5_ex4_slide1_content:
Create your own exception by extending Exception.

Like custom errors: 'Age cannot be negative!'
ro.java_lesson5_ex5_slide1_content:
try-with-resources automatically closes resources.

Like auto-return library books!
ro.java_lesson5_ex6_slide1_content:
BufferedReader reads text efficiently.

Reads line by line instead of character by character!
ro.java_lesson5_ex7_slide1_content:
BufferedWriter writes text efficiently.

Batches writes instead of one character at a time!
ro.java_lesson5_ex8_slide1_content:
Scanner parses text into words and numbers.

From '10 20 30', extract 10, 20, 30 as numbers!
ro.java_lesson5_ex8_slide2_content:
nextInt()    // Read integer
nextDouble() // Read decimal
next()       // Read word
nextLine()   // Read line
ro.java_lesson5_ex9_slide1_content:
Java 7's Files class makes file operations easy.

Like automatic doors - easier than manual!
ro.java_lesson5_ex9_slide2_content:
Files.readAllLines(path)  // Read all lines
Files.readString(path)    // Read as string
Files.write(path, lines)  // Write
Files.exists(path)        // Check existence
ro.java_lesson5_ex10_slide1_content:
Use | to catch multiple exception types together.

'If apple OR orange falls, catch it!'

Deque

ru.java_lesson1_course_description: Learn the basics of Java, a strict but reliable language. Master the rules to give computers precise instructions.
ru.java_lesson2_course_description: After mastering basics, dive into object-oriented programming! Learn inheritance, interfaces, and exception handling.
ru.java_lesson3_course_description: Learn Java 8+ features. Stream API, lambda expressions, Optional - master modern Java.
ru.java_lesson4_course_description: Learn advanced generics and collections. Write type-safe code with important concepts.
ru.java_lesson5_course_description: Learn exception handling and file I/O. Essential skills for robust programs.
ru.java_lesson1_ex1_slide1_content:
Java is a reliable programming language used worldwide in banks and Android apps.

Think of Java as a strict teacher - rules are tough, but they help you write safe programs with fewer mistakes.
ru.java_lesson1_ex2_slide1_content:
Variables are like labeled drawers that store data.

Just like 'snack drawer' or 'toy drawer', give your variables meaningful names!
ru.java_lesson1_ex3_slide1_content:
Use int (integer) for whole numbers.

Rules:
- Text -> String
- Numbers -> int
ru.java_lesson1_ex4_slide1_content:
% gives the remainder of division.

Example: 10 candies shared by 3 people = 3 each, 1 remains!
ru.java_lesson1_ex6_slide1_content:
Concatenation joins text and variables using +.

Like connecting puzzle pieces!
ru.java_lesson1_ex7_slide1_content:
Arrays are like numbered lockers that hold data in order.

Great for shopping lists or class rosters!
ru.java_lesson1_ex8_slide1_content:
Make decisions based on conditions.

Like a fork in the road - if score >= 80, pass; otherwise, fail.
ru.java_lesson1_ex9_slide1_content:
else handles the alternative case.

If sunny, play outside; otherwise, play games inside.
ru.java_lesson1_ex10_slide1_content:
&& (AND): both must be true
|| (OR): either can be true

Like amusement park rules: height >= 120cm AND age >= 10
ru.java_lesson1_ex11_comment2: Loop through names with variable name
ru.java_lesson1_ex11_slide1_content:
Loops repeat actions automatically.

Instead of calling each name individually, loop says 'call everyone in order'!
ru.java_lesson1_ex12_slide1_content:
HashMap stores key-value pairs, like a dictionary.

Look up 'apple' and get 'red fruit'!
ru.java_lesson1_ex13_slide1_content:
Methods are reusable code blocks with names.

Like special moves in games - call the name and it executes!
ru.java_lesson2_ex1_slide1_content:
Inheritance lets a child class inherit features from a parent class.

Like inheriting eye color from parents!
ru.java_lesson2_ex2_slide1_content:
Override means rewriting a parent's method in the child class.

Animals make sounds, but dogs say 'Woof!' and cats say 'Meow!'
ru.java_lesson2_ex3_slide1_content:
Interface defines methods a class must have - like a contract.

If you have a driver's license (implements), you can drive (have the method)!
ru.java_lesson2_ex3_slide2_content:
A class can implement multiple interfaces.

Like having both a driver's license and a cooking license!
ru.java_lesson2_ex4_slide1_content:
Abstract classes are incomplete blueprints that can't be instantiated directly.

'Animal' exists but you can't create a generic 'animal' - only specific ones like dogs or cats.
ru.java_lesson2_ex5_comment2: Convert string to int with parseInt
ru.java_lesson2_ex5_slide1_content:
Exceptions are unexpected problems during execution.

Like running out of sugar while cooking - can't follow the recipe!
ru.java_lesson2_ex6_slide1_content:
finally always runs, whether exception occurs or not.

Like always cleaning up the kitchen after cooking, success or fail!
ru.java_lesson2_ex7_slide1_content:
ArrayList is a resizable list.

Like an expandable bookshelf - add or remove books freely!
ru.java_lesson2_ex7_slide2_content:
ArrayList<Integer> nums = new ArrayList<>();
nums.add(10);    // Add
nums.get(0);     // Get -> 10
nums.remove(0);  // Remove
nums.size();     // Size
ru.java_lesson2_ex8_slide1_content:
Enhanced for easily processes all elements.

'Wash ALL fruits in this basket' - process everything in order!
ru.java_lesson2_ex9_slide1_content:
Static methods can be called without creating an instance.

Like a shared toolbox everyone can use!
ru.java_lesson2_ex10_slide1_content:
Access modifiers control who can access data.

public: Anyone can access
private: Only this class
protected: Child classes too
ru.java_lesson2_ex10_slide2_content:
Hide important data with private, access via methods.

Like bank accounts - can't change balance directly, must use deposit/withdraw!
ru.java_lesson3_ex1_slide1_content:
Lambda expressions write functions concisely.

x -> x * 2 means 'take x, return x times 2'
ru.java_lesson3_ex1_slide2_content:
() -> System.out.println("Hello")  // No params
x -> x * 2  // One param
(a, b) -> a + b  // Multiple params
ru.java_lesson3_ex2_slide1_content: Stream is an API for processing collection elements in sequence.
ru.java_lesson3_ex2_slide2_content:
list.stream()  // From collection
Arrays.stream(array)  // From array
Stream.of(1, 2, 3)  // From values
ru.java_lesson3_ex3_slide1_content:
map applies a function to each element.

nums.stream().map(n -> n * 2) doubles each number.
ru.java_lesson3_ex4_slide1_content:
filter keeps only elements matching a condition.

.filter(n -> n > 2) keeps numbers greater than 2.
ru.java_lesson3_ex5_slide1_content:
collect converts Stream results to a collection.

.collect(Collectors.toList()) creates a List.
ru.java_lesson3_ex5_slide2_content:
Collectors.toList()  // To List
Collectors.toSet()   // To Set
Collectors.joining(", ")  // Join strings
ru.java_lesson3_ex6_slide1_content:
reduce combines all elements into one value.

.reduce(0, (a, b) -> a + b) sums all numbers.
ru.java_lesson3_ex6_slide2_content:
.reduce(0, Integer::sum)  // Sum
.reduce(1, (a, b) -> a * b)  // Product
ru.java_lesson3_ex7_slide1_content:
Optional represents a value that may or may not exist.

Safely handle potentially null values!
ru.java_lesson3_ex7_slide2_content:
opt.orElse("default")  // Value or default
opt.ifPresent(System.out::println)  // If exists, process
ru.java_lesson3_ex8_slide1_content:
:: references existing methods as lambdas.

x -> System.out.println(x) becomes System.out::println
ru.java_lesson3_ex8_slide2_content:
Integer::parseInt  // Static method
System.out::println  // Instance method
String::length  // Any instance
ArrayList::new  // Constructor
ru.java_lesson3_ex9_slide1_content: sorted sorts elements in natural order.
ru.java_lesson4_ex1_slide1_content:
Generics let you specify types later.

Like a box that becomes 'String box' or 'Integer box' when you use it!
ru.java_lesson4_ex2_comment1: Limit type upper bound with extends
ru.java_lesson4_ex2_slide1_content:
extends limits which types are allowed.

<T extends Number> only accepts Number or its subclasses.
ru.java_lesson4_ex2_slide2_content:
NumBox<Integer> box = new NumBox<>();  // OK
NumBox<String> box2;  // Error! String isn't a Number
ru.java_lesson4_ex3_slide1_content:
? means 'any type' - like a joker card!

List<?> accepts List<String>, List<Integer>, etc.
ru.java_lesson4_ex3_slide2_content:
List<? extends Number>  // Number or subclass
List<? super Integer>   // Integer or superclass
ru.java_lesson4_ex4_slide1_content:
Map stores key-value pairs.

Like a phone book - look up name (key), get number (value)!
ru.java_lesson4_ex4_slide2_content:
containsKey("Alice")  // Check if key exists
getOrDefault("Bob", 0)  // Default if not found
keySet()  // All keys
values()  // All values
ru.java_lesson4_ex5_slide1_content:
entrySet gets all key-value pairs.

Like flipping through every page of a phone book!
ru.java_lesson4_ex6_comment1: Create list with new and asList
ru.java_lesson4_ex6_slide1_content:
Comparator defines how to sort.

Sort books by title, author, or year - you decide!
ru.java_lesson4_ex6_slide2_content:
Comparator.naturalOrder()  // Natural order
Comparator.reverseOrder()  // Reverse
Comparator.comparing(Person::getName)  // By property
ru.java_lesson4_ex7_slide1_content:
Implementing Comparable defines natural ordering for your class.

Like numbers having a natural order: 1 < 2 < 3
ru.java_lesson4_ex7_slide2_content:
this < other -> negative
this == other -> 0
this > other -> positive

return this.age - other.age;
ru.java_lesson4_ex8_slide1_content:
Enum defines a fixed set of constants.

Traffic lights: only RED, YELLOW, GREEN - nothing else!
ru.java_lesson4_ex9_slide1_content:
Queue is FIFO (First In, First Out).

Like a line at an amusement park - first in line rides first!
ru.java_lesson4_ex9_slide2_content:
offer(e)  // Add to end
poll()    // Remove from front (null if empty)
peek()    // Look at front (don't remove)
ru.java_lesson4_ex10_slide1_content:
Deque (Double-Ended Queue) allows operations at both ends.

Like a train with doors at both ends!
ru.java_lesson4_ex10_slide2_content:
Deque can be used as a LIFO stack.

stack.push(1);  // Push 1
stack.push(2);  // Push 2 (on top)
stack.pop();    // Pop 2 (top comes first)
ru.java_lesson5_ex1_slide1_content:
Exceptions are unexpected problems during execution.

Like breaking a plate while cooking!
ru.java_lesson5_ex2_slide1_content:
finally always executes, success or fail.

Always clean up the kitchen after cooking!
ru.java_lesson5_ex3_slide1_content:
throws declares that a method might throw an exception.

Warning label: 'This might explode, handle with care!'
ru.java_lesson5_ex3_slide2_content:
Caller must either catch or re-throw.

1. Catch it yourself
2. Pass it up with throws
ru.java_lesson5_ex4_slide1_content:
Create your own exception by extending Exception.

Like custom errors: 'Age cannot be negative!'
ru.java_lesson5_ex5_slide1_content:
try-with-resources automatically closes resources.

Like auto-return library books!
ru.java_lesson5_ex6_slide1_content:
BufferedReader reads text efficiently.

Reads line by line instead of character by character!
ru.java_lesson5_ex7_slide1_content:
BufferedWriter writes text efficiently.

Batches writes instead of one character at a time!
ru.java_lesson5_ex8_slide1_content:
Scanner parses text into words and numbers.

From '10 20 30', extract 10, 20, 30 as numbers!
ru.java_lesson5_ex8_slide2_content:
nextInt()    // Read integer
nextDouble() // Read decimal
next()       // Read word
nextLine()   // Read line
ru.java_lesson5_ex9_slide1_content:
Java 7's Files class makes file operations easy.

Like automatic doors - easier than manual!
ru.java_lesson5_ex9_slide2_content:
Files.readAllLines(path)  // Read all lines
Files.readString(path)    // Read as string
Files.write(path, lines)  // Write
Files.exists(path)        // Check existence

Use | to catch multiple exception types together.

'If apple OR orange falls, catch it!'

Deque

sv.java_lesson1_course_description: Learn the basics of Java, a strict but reliable language. Master the rules to give computers precise instructions.
sv.java_lesson2_course_description: After mastering basics, dive into object-oriented programming! Learn inheritance, interfaces, and exception handling.
sv.java_lesson3_course_description: Learn Java 8+ features. Stream API, lambda expressions, Optional - master modern Java.
sv.java_lesson4_course_description: Learn advanced generics and collections. Write type-safe code with important concepts.
sv.java_lesson5_course_description: Learn exception handling and file I/O. Essential skills for robust programs.
sv.java_lesson1_ex1_slide1_content:
Java is a reliable programming language used worldwide in banks and Android apps.

Think of Java as a strict teacher - rules are tough, but they help you write safe programs with fewer mistakes.
sv.java_lesson1_ex2_slide1_content:
Variables are like labeled drawers that store data.

Just like 'snack drawer' or 'toy drawer', give your variables meaningful names!
sv.java_lesson1_ex3_slide1_content:
Use int (integer) for whole numbers.

Rules:
- Text -> String
- Numbers -> int
sv.java_lesson1_ex4_slide1_content:
% gives the remainder of division.

Example: 10 candies shared by 3 people = 3 each, 1 remains!
sv.java_lesson1_ex6_slide1_content:
Concatenation joins text and variables using +.

Like connecting puzzle pieces!
sv.java_lesson1_ex7_slide1_content:
Arrays are like numbered lockers that hold data in order.

Great for shopping lists or class rosters!
sv.java_lesson1_ex8_slide1_content:
Make decisions based on conditions.

Like a fork in the road - if score >= 80, pass; otherwise, fail.
sv.java_lesson1_ex9_slide1_content:
else handles the alternative case.

If sunny, play outside; otherwise, play games inside.
sv.java_lesson1_ex10_slide1_content:
&& (AND): both must be true
|| (OR): either can be true

Like amusement park rules: height >= 120cm AND age >= 10
sv.java_lesson1_ex11_comment2: Loop through names with variable name
sv.java_lesson1_ex11_slide1_content:
Loops repeat actions automatically.

Instead of calling each name individually, loop says 'call everyone in order'!
sv.java_lesson1_ex12_slide1_content:
HashMap stores key-value pairs, like a dictionary.

Look up 'apple' and get 'red fruit'!
sv.java_lesson1_ex13_slide1_content:
Methods are reusable code blocks with names.

Like special moves in games - call the name and it executes!
sv.java_lesson2_ex1_slide1_content:
Inheritance lets a child class inherit features from a parent class.

Like inheriting eye color from parents!
sv.java_lesson2_ex2_slide1_content:
Override means rewriting a parent's method in the child class.

Animals make sounds, but dogs say 'Woof!' and cats say 'Meow!'
sv.java_lesson2_ex3_slide1_content:
Interface defines methods a class must have - like a contract.

If you have a driver's license (implements), you can drive (have the method)!
sv.java_lesson2_ex3_slide2_content:
A class can implement multiple interfaces.

Like having both a driver's license and a cooking license!
sv.java_lesson2_ex4_slide1_content:
Abstract classes are incomplete blueprints that can't be instantiated directly.

'Animal' exists but you can't create a generic 'animal' - only specific ones like dogs or cats.
sv.java_lesson2_ex5_comment2: Convert string to int with parseInt
sv.java_lesson2_ex5_slide1_content:
Exceptions are unexpected problems during execution.

Like running out of sugar while cooking - can't follow the recipe!
sv.java_lesson2_ex6_slide1_content:
finally always runs, whether exception occurs or not.

Like always cleaning up the kitchen after cooking, success or fail!
sv.java_lesson2_ex7_slide1_content:
ArrayList is a resizable list.

Like an expandable bookshelf - add or remove books freely!
sv.java_lesson2_ex7_slide2_content:
ArrayList<Integer> nums = new ArrayList<>();
nums.add(10);    // Add
nums.get(0);     // Get -> 10
nums.remove(0);  // Remove
nums.size();     // Size
sv.java_lesson2_ex8_slide1_content:
Enhanced for easily processes all elements.

'Wash ALL fruits in this basket' - process everything in order!
sv.java_lesson2_ex9_slide1_content:
Static methods can be called without creating an instance.

Like a shared toolbox everyone can use!
sv.java_lesson2_ex10_slide1_content:
Access modifiers control who can access data.

public: Anyone can access
private: Only this class
protected: Child classes too
sv.java_lesson2_ex10_slide2_content:
Hide important data with private, access via methods.

Like bank accounts - can't change balance directly, must use deposit/withdraw!
sv.java_lesson3_ex1_slide1_content:
Lambda expressions write functions concisely.

x -> x * 2 means 'take x, return x times 2'
sv.java_lesson3_ex1_slide2_content:
() -> System.out.println("Hello")  // No params
x -> x * 2  // One param
(a, b) -> a + b  // Multiple params
sv.java_lesson3_ex2_slide1_content: Stream is an API for processing collection elements in sequence.
sv.java_lesson3_ex2_slide2_content:
list.stream()  // From collection
Arrays.stream(array)  // From array
Stream.of(1, 2, 3)  // From values
sv.java_lesson3_ex3_slide1_content:
map applies a function to each element.

nums.stream().map(n -> n * 2) doubles each number.
sv.java_lesson3_ex4_slide1_content:
filter keeps only elements matching a condition.

.filter(n -> n > 2) keeps numbers greater than 2.
sv.java_lesson3_ex5_slide1_content:
collect converts Stream results to a collection.

.collect(Collectors.toList()) creates a List.
sv.java_lesson3_ex5_slide2_content:
Collectors.toList()  // To List
Collectors.toSet()   // To Set
Collectors.joining(", ")  // Join strings
sv.java_lesson3_ex6_slide1_content:
reduce combines all elements into one value.

.reduce(0, (a, b) -> a + b) sums all numbers.
sv.java_lesson3_ex6_slide2_content:
.reduce(0, Integer::sum)  // Sum
.reduce(1, (a, b) -> a * b)  // Product
sv.java_lesson3_ex7_slide1_content:
Optional represents a value that may or may not exist.

Safely handle potentially null values!
sv.java_lesson3_ex7_slide2_content:
opt.orElse("default")  // Value or default
opt.ifPresent(System.out::println)  // If exists, process
sv.java_lesson3_ex8_slide1_content:
:: references existing methods as lambdas.

x -> System.out.println(x) becomes System.out::println
sv.java_lesson3_ex8_slide2_content:
Integer::parseInt  // Static method
System.out::println  // Instance method
String::length  // Any instance
ArrayList::new  // Constructor
sv.java_lesson3_ex9_slide1_content: sorted sorts elements in natural order.
sv.java_lesson4_ex1_slide1_content:
Generics let you specify types later.

Like a box that becomes 'String box' or 'Integer box' when you use it!
sv.java_lesson4_ex2_comment1: Limit type upper bound with extends
sv.java_lesson4_ex2_slide1_content:
extends limits which types are allowed.

<T extends Number> only accepts Number or its subclasses.
sv.java_lesson4_ex2_slide2_content:
NumBox<Integer> box = new NumBox<>();  // OK
NumBox<String> box2;  // Error! String isn't a Number
sv.java_lesson4_ex3_slide1_content:
? means 'any type' - like a joker card!

List<?> accepts List<String>, List<Integer>, etc.
sv.java_lesson4_ex3_slide2_content:
List<? extends Number>  // Number or subclass
List<? super Integer>   // Integer or superclass
sv.java_lesson4_ex4_slide1_content:
Map stores key-value pairs.

Like a phone book - look up name (key), get number (value)!
sv.java_lesson4_ex4_slide2_content:
containsKey("Alice")  // Check if key exists
getOrDefault("Bob", 0)  // Default if not found
keySet()  // All keys
values()  // All values
sv.java_lesson4_ex5_slide1_content:
entrySet gets all key-value pairs.

Like flipping through every page of a phone book!
sv.java_lesson4_ex6_comment1: Create list with new and asList
sv.java_lesson4_ex6_slide1_content:
Comparator defines how to sort.

Sort books by title, author, or year - you decide!

Comparator.reverseOrder()  // Reverse
Comparator.comparing(Person::getName)  // By property
sv.java_lesson4_ex7_slide1_content:
Implementing Comparable defines natural ordering for your class.

Like numbers having a natural order: 1 < 2 < 3
sv.java_lesson4_ex7_slide2_content:
this < other -> negative
this == other -> 0
this > other -> positive

return this.age - other.age;

Traffic lights: only RED, YELLOW, GREEN - nothing else!

Like a line at an amusement park - first in line rides first!

poll()    // Remove from front (null if empty)
peek()    // Look at front (don't remove)
sv.java_lesson4_ex10_slide1_content:
Deque (Double-Ended Queue) allows operations at both ends.

Like a train with doors at both ends!
sv.java_lesson4_ex10_slide2_content:
Deque can be used as a LIFO stack.

stack.push(1);  // Push 1
stack.push(2);  // Push 2 (on top)
stack.pop();    // Pop 2 (top comes first)
sv.java_lesson5_ex1_slide1_content:
Exceptions are unexpected problems during execution.

Like breaking a plate while cooking!
sv.java_lesson5_ex2_slide1_content:
finally always executes, success or fail.

Always clean up the kitchen after cooking!
sv.java_lesson5_ex3_slide1_content:
throws declares that a method might throw an exception.

Warning label: 'This might explode, handle with care!'
sv.java_lesson5_ex3_slide2_content:
Caller must either catch or re-throw.

1. Catch it yourself
2. Pass it up with throws
sv.java_lesson5_ex4_slide1_content:
Create your own exception by extending Exception.

Like custom errors: 'Age cannot be negative!'

try-with-resources automatically closes resources.

Like auto-return library books!

BufferedReader reads text efficiently.

Reads line by line instead of character by character!

Batches writes instead of one character at a time!

Scanner parses text into words and numbers.

From '10 20 30', extract 10, 20, 30 as numbers!

next()       // Read word

Hide important data with private, access via methods.

Like bank accounts - can't change balance directly, must use deposit/withdraw!
tr.java_lesson3_ex1_slide1_content:
Lambda expressions write functions concisely.

x -> x * 2 means 'take x, return x times 2'
tr.java_lesson3_ex1_slide2_content:
() -> System.out.println("Hello")  // No params
x -> x * 2  // One param
(a, b) -> a + b  // Multiple params
tr.java_lesson3_ex2_slide1_content: Stream is an API for processing collection elements in sequence.
tr.java_lesson3_ex2_slide2_content:
list.stream()  // From collection
Arrays.stream(array)  // From array
Stream.of(1, 2, 3)  // From values
tr.java_lesson3_ex3_slide1_content:
map applies a function to each element.

nums.stream().map(n -> n * 2) doubles each number.
tr.java_lesson3_ex4_slide1_content:
filter keeps only elements matching a condition.

.filter(n -> n > 2) keeps numbers greater than 2.
tr.java_lesson3_ex5_slide1_content:
collect converts Stream results to a collection.

.collect(Collectors.toList()) creates a List.
tr.java_lesson3_ex5_slide2_content:
Collectors.toList()  // To List
Collectors.toSet()   // To Set
Collectors.joining(", ")  // Join strings
tr.java_lesson3_ex6_slide1_content:
reduce combines all elements into one value.

.reduce(0, (a, b) -> a + b) sums all numbers.
tr.java_lesson3_ex6_slide2_content:
.reduce(0, Integer::sum)  // Sum
.reduce(1, (a, b) -> a * b)  // Product
tr.java_lesson3_ex7_slide1_content:
Optional represents a value that may or may not exist.

Safely handle potentially null values!
tr.java_lesson3_ex7_slide2_content:
opt.orElse("default")  // Value or default
opt.ifPresent(System.out::println)  // If exists, process
tr.java_lesson3_ex8_slide1_content:
:: references existing methods as lambdas.

x -> System.out.println(x) becomes System.out::println
tr.java_lesson3_ex8_slide2_content:
Integer::parseInt  // Static method
System.out::println  // Instance method
String::length  // Any instance
ArrayList::new  // Constructor
tr.java_lesson3_ex9_slide1_content: sorted sorts elements in natural order.
tr.java_lesson4_ex1_slide1_content:
Generics let you specify types later.

Like a box that becomes 'String box' or 'Integer box' when you use it!

tr.java_lesson4_ex2_slide1_content:
extends limits which types are allowed.

<T extends Number> only accepts Number or its subclasses.

tr.java_lesson4_ex4_slide1_content:

Like a phone book - look up name (key), get number (value)!

keySet()  // All keys
values()  // All values
tr.java_lesson4_ex5_slide1_content:

Deque (Double-Ended Queue) allows operations at both ends.

stack.push(1);  // Push 1

Like breaking a plate while cooking!

zh-Hans.java_lesson1_course_description: Learn the basics of Java, a strict but reliable language. Master the rules to give computers precise instructions.
zh-Hans.java_lesson2_course_description: After mastering basics, dive into object-oriented programming! Learn inheritance, interfaces, and exception handling.
zh-Hans.java_lesson3_course_description: Learn Java 8+ features. Stream API, lambda expressions, Optional - master modern Java.
zh-Hans.java_lesson4_course_description: Learn advanced generics and collections. Write type-safe code with important concepts.
zh-Hans.java_lesson5_course_description: Learn exception handling and file I/O. Essential skills for robust programs.
zh-Hans.java_lesson1_ex1_slide1_content:
Java is a reliable programming language used worldwide in banks and Android apps.

Think of Java as a strict teacher - rules are tough, but they help you write safe programs with fewer mistakes.
zh-Hans.java_lesson1_ex2_slide1_content:
Variables are like labeled drawers that store data.

Just like 'snack drawer' or 'toy drawer', give your variables meaningful names!
zh-Hans.java_lesson1_ex3_slide1_content:
Use int (integer) for whole numbers.

Rules:
- Text -> String
- Numbers -> int
zh-Hans.java_lesson1_ex4_slide1_content:
% gives the remainder of division.

Example: 10 candies shared by 3 people = 3 each, 1 remains!
zh-Hans.java_lesson1_ex6_slide1_content:
Concatenation joins text and variables using +.

Like connecting puzzle pieces!
zh-Hans.java_lesson1_ex7_slide1_content:
Arrays are like numbered lockers that hold data in order.

Great for shopping lists or class rosters!
zh-Hans.java_lesson1_ex8_slide1_content:
Make decisions based on conditions.

Like a fork in the road - if score >= 80, pass; otherwise, fail.
zh-Hans.java_lesson1_ex9_slide1_content:
else handles the alternative case.

If sunny, play outside; otherwise, play games inside.
zh-Hans.java_lesson1_ex10_slide1_content:
&& (AND): both must be true
|| (OR): either can be true

Like amusement park rules: height >= 120cm AND age >= 10
zh-Hans.java_lesson1_ex11_comment2: Loop through names with variable name
zh-Hans.java_lesson1_ex11_slide1_content:
Loops repeat actions automatically.

Instead of calling each name individually, loop says 'call everyone in order'!
zh-Hans.java_lesson1_ex12_slide1_content:
HashMap stores key-value pairs, like a dictionary.

Look up 'apple' and get 'red fruit'!
zh-Hans.java_lesson1_ex13_slide1_content:
Methods are reusable code blocks with names.

Like special moves in games - call the name and it executes!
zh-Hans.java_lesson2_ex1_slide1_content:
Inheritance lets a child class inherit features from a parent class.

Like inheriting eye color from parents!
zh-Hans.java_lesson2_ex2_slide1_content:
Override means rewriting a parent's method in the child class.

Animals make sounds, but dogs say 'Woof!' and cats say 'Meow!'
zh-Hans.java_lesson2_ex3_slide1_content:
Interface defines methods a class must have - like a contract.

If you have a driver's license (implements), you can drive (have the method)!
zh-Hans.java_lesson2_ex3_slide2_content:
A class can implement multiple interfaces.

Like having both a driver's license and a cooking license!
zh-Hans.java_lesson2_ex4_slide1_content:
Abstract classes are incomplete blueprints that can't be instantiated directly.

'Animal' exists but you can't create a generic 'animal' - only specific ones like dogs or cats.
zh-Hans.java_lesson2_ex5_comment2: Convert string to int with parseInt
zh-Hans.java_lesson2_ex5_slide1_content:
Exceptions are unexpected problems during execution.

Like running out of sugar while cooking - can't follow the recipe!
zh-Hans.java_lesson2_ex6_slide1_content:
finally always runs, whether exception occurs or not.

Like always cleaning up the kitchen after cooking, success or fail!
zh-Hans.java_lesson2_ex7_slide1_content:
ArrayList is a resizable list.

Like an expandable bookshelf - add or remove books freely!
zh-Hans.java_lesson2_ex7_slide2_content:
ArrayList<Integer> nums = new ArrayList<>();
nums.add(10);    // Add
nums.get(0);     // Get -> 10
nums.remove(0);  // Remove
nums.size();     // Size
zh-Hans.java_lesson2_ex8_slide1_content:
Enhanced for easily processes all elements.

'Wash ALL fruits in this basket' - process everything in order!
zh-Hans.java_lesson2_ex9_slide1_content:
Static methods can be called without creating an instance.

Like a shared toolbox everyone can use!

public: Anyone can access
private: Only this class
protected: Child classes too
zh-Hans.java_lesson2_ex10_slide2_content:
Hide important data with private, access via methods.

Like bank accounts - can't change balance directly, must use deposit/withdraw!

x -> x * 2 means 'take x, return x times 2'

x -> x * 2  // One param
(a, b) -> a + b  // Multiple params

.filter(n -> n > 2) keeps numbers greater than 2.

.collect(Collectors.toList()) creates a List.

Like connecting puzzle pieces!
zh-Hant.java_lesson1_ex7_slide1_content:
Arrays are like numbered lockers that hold data in order.

Great for shopping lists or class rosters!
zh-Hant.java_lesson1_ex8_slide1_content:
Make decisions based on conditions.

Like a fork in the road - if score >= 80, pass; otherwise, fail.
zh-Hant.java_lesson1_ex9_slide1_content:
else handles the alternative case.

If sunny, play outside; otherwise, play games inside.
zh-Hant.java_lesson1_ex10_slide1_content:
&& (AND): both must be true
|| (OR): either can be true

Like amusement park rules: height >= 120cm AND age >= 10
zh-Hant.java_lesson1_ex11_comment2: Loop through names with variable name
zh-Hant.java_lesson1_ex11_slide1_content:
Loops repeat actions automatically.

Instead of calling each name individually, loop says 'call everyone in order'!
zh-Hant.java_lesson1_ex12_slide1_content:
HashMap stores key-value pairs, like a dictionary.

Look up 'apple' and get 'red fruit'!
zh-Hant.java_lesson1_ex13_slide1_content:
Methods are reusable code blocks with names.

Like special moves in games - call the name and it executes!
zh-Hant.java_lesson2_ex1_slide1_content:
Inheritance lets a child class inherit features from a parent class.

Like inheriting eye color from parents!
zh-Hant.java_lesson2_ex2_slide1_content:
Override means rewriting a parent's method in the child class.

Animals make sounds, but dogs say 'Woof!' and cats say 'Meow!'
zh-Hant.java_lesson2_ex3_slide1_content:
Interface defines methods a class must have - like a contract.

If you have a driver's license (implements), you can drive (have the method)!
zh-Hant.java_lesson2_ex3_slide2_content:
A class can implement multiple interfaces.

Like having both a driver's license and a cooking license!
zh-Hant.java_lesson2_ex4_slide1_content:
Abstract classes are incomplete blueprints that can't be instantiated directly.

'Animal' exists but you can't create a generic 'animal' - only specific ones like dogs or cats.
zh-Hant.java_lesson2_ex5_comment2: Convert string to int with parseInt
zh-Hant.java_lesson2_ex5_slide1_content:
Exceptions are unexpected problems during execution.

Like running out of sugar while cooking - can't follow the recipe!
zh-Hant.java_lesson2_ex6_slide1_content:
finally always runs, whether exception occurs or not.

Like always cleaning up the kitchen after cooking, success or fail!
zh-Hant.java_lesson2_ex7_slide1_content:
ArrayList is a resizable list.

Like an expandable bookshelf - add or remove books freely!
zh-Hant.java_lesson2_ex7_slide2_content:
ArrayList<Integer> nums = new ArrayList<>();
nums.add(10);    // Add
nums.get(0);     // Get -> 10
nums.remove(0);  // Remove
nums.size();     // Size
zh-Hant.java_lesson2_ex8_slide1_content:
Enhanced for easily processes all elements.

'Wash ALL fruits in this basket' - process everything in order!
zh-Hant.java_lesson2_ex9_slide1_content:
Static methods can be called without creating an instance.

Like a shared toolbox everyone can use!
zh-Hant.java_lesson2_ex10_slide1_content:
Access modifiers control who can access data.

public: Anyone can access
private: Only this class
protected: Child classes too
zh-Hant.java_lesson2_ex10_slide2_content:
Hide important data with private, access via methods.

Like bank accounts - can't change balance directly, must use deposit/withdraw!
zh-Hant.java_lesson3_ex1_slide1_content:
Lambda expressions write functions concisely.

x -> x * 2 means 'take x, return x times 2'
zh-Hant.java_lesson3_ex1_slide2_content:
() -> System.out.println("Hello")  // No params
x -> x * 2  // One param
(a, b) -> a + b  // Multiple params
zh-Hant.java_lesson3_ex2_slide1_content: Stream is an API for processing collection elements in sequence.
zh-Hant.java_lesson3_ex2_slide2_content:
list.stream()  // From collection
Arrays.stream(array)  // From array
Stream.of(1, 2, 3)  // From values
zh-Hant.java_lesson3_ex3_slide1_content:
map applies a function to each element.

nums.stream().map(n -> n * 2) doubles each number.
zh-Hant.java_lesson3_ex4_slide1_content:
filter keeps only elements matching a condition.

.filter(n -> n > 2) keeps numbers greater than 2.
zh-Hant.java_lesson3_ex5_slide1_content:
collect converts Stream results to a collection.

.collect(Collectors.toList()) creates a List.
zh-Hant.java_lesson3_ex5_slide2_content:
Collectors.toList()  // To List
Collectors.toSet()   // To Set
Collectors.joining(", ")  // Join strings
zh-Hant.java_lesson3_ex6_slide1_content:
reduce combines all elements into one value.

.reduce(0, (a, b) -> a + b) sums all numbers.
zh-Hant.java_lesson3_ex6_slide2_content:
.reduce(0, Integer::sum)  // Sum
.reduce(1, (a, b) -> a * b)  // Product
zh-Hant.java_lesson3_ex7_slide1_content:
Optional represents a value that may or may not exist.

Safely handle potentially null values!
zh-Hant.java_lesson3_ex7_slide2_content:
opt.orElse("default")  // Value or default
opt.ifPresent(System.out::println)  // If exists, process
zh-Hant.java_lesson3_ex8_slide1_content:
:: references existing methods as lambdas.

x -> System.out.println(x) becomes System.out::println
zh-Hant.java_lesson3_ex8_slide2_content:
Integer::parseInt  // Static method
System.out::println  // Instance method
String::length  // Any instance
ArrayList::new  // Constructor
zh-Hant.java_lesson3_ex9_slide1_content: sorted sorts elements in natural order.
zh-Hant.java_lesson4_ex1_slide1_content:
Generics let you specify types later.

Like a box that becomes 'String box' or 'Integer box' when you use it!
zh-Hant.java_lesson4_ex2_comment1: Limit type upper bound with extends
zh-Hant.java_lesson4_ex2_slide1_content:
extends limits which types are allowed.

<T extends Number> only accepts Number or its subclasses.
zh-Hant.java_lesson4_ex2_slide2_content:
NumBox<Integer> box = new NumBox<>();  // OK
NumBox<String> box2;  // Error! String isn't a Number
zh-Hant.java_lesson4_ex3_slide1_content:
? means 'any type' - like a joker card!

List<?> accepts List<String>, List<Integer>, etc.
zh-Hant.java_lesson4_ex3_slide2_content:
List<? extends Number>  // Number or subclass
List<? super Integer>   // Integer or superclass
zh-Hant.java_lesson4_ex4_slide1_content:
Map stores key-value pairs.

Like a phone book - look up name (key), get number (value)!
zh-Hant.java_lesson4_ex4_slide2_content:
containsKey("Alice")  // Check if key exists
getOrDefault("Bob", 0)  // Default if not found
keySet()  // All keys
values()  // All values
zh-Hant.java_lesson4_ex5_slide1_content:
entrySet gets all key-value pairs.

Like flipping through every page of a phone book!
zh-Hant.java_lesson4_ex6_comment1: Create list with new and asList
zh-Hant.java_lesson4_ex6_slide1_content:
Comparator defines how to sort.

Sort books by title, author, or year - you decide!
zh-Hant.java_lesson4_ex6_slide2_content:
Comparator.naturalOrder()  // Natural order
Comparator.reverseOrder()  // Reverse
Comparator.comparing(Person::getName)  // By property
zh-Hant.java_lesson4_ex7_slide1_content:
Implementing Comparable defines natural ordering for your class.

Like numbers having a natural order: 1 < 2 < 3
zh-Hant.java_lesson4_ex7_slide2_content:
this < other -> negative
this == other -> 0
this > other -> positive

return this.age - other.age;
zh-Hant.java_lesson4_ex8_slide1_content:
Enum defines a fixed set of constants.

Traffic lights: only RED, YELLOW, GREEN - nothing else!
zh-Hant.java_lesson4_ex9_slide1_content:
Queue is FIFO (First In, First Out).

Like a line at an amusement park - first in line rides first!
zh-Hant.java_lesson4_ex9_slide2_content:
offer(e)  // Add to end
poll()    // Remove from front (null if empty)
peek()    // Look at front (don't remove)
zh-Hant.java_lesson4_ex10_slide1_content:
Deque (Double-Ended Queue) allows operations at both ends.

Like a train with doors at both ends!
zh-Hant.java_lesson4_ex10_slide2_content:
Deque can be used as a LIFO stack.

stack.push(1);  // Push 1
stack.push(2);  // Push 2 (on top)
stack.pop();    // Pop 2 (top comes first)
zh-Hant.java_lesson5_ex1_slide1_content:
Exceptions are unexpected problems during execution.

Like breaking a plate while cooking!
zh-Hant.java_lesson5_ex2_slide1_content:
finally always executes, success or fail.

Always clean up the kitchen after cooking!
zh-Hant.java_lesson5_ex3_slide1_content:
throws declares that a method might throw an exception.

Warning label: 'This might explode, handle with care!'
zh-Hant.java_lesson5_ex3_slide2_content:
Caller must either catch or re-throw.

1. Catch it yourself
2. Pass it up with throws
zh-Hant.java_lesson5_ex4_slide1_content:
Create your own exception by extending Exception.

Like custom errors: 'Age cannot be negative!'
zh-Hant.java_lesson5_ex5_slide1_content:
try-with-resources automatically closes resources.

Like auto-return library books!
zh-Hant.java_lesson5_ex6_slide1_content:
BufferedReader reads text efficiently.

Reads line by line instead of character by character!
zh-Hant.java_lesson5_ex7_slide1_content:
BufferedWriter writes text efficiently.

Batches writes instead of one character at a time!
zh-Hant.java_lesson5_ex8_slide1_content:
Scanner parses text into words and numbers.

From '10 20 30', extract 10, 20, 30 as numbers!
zh-Hant.java_lesson5_ex8_slide2_content:
nextInt()    // Read integer
nextDouble() // Read decimal
next()       // Read word
nextLine()   // Read line
zh-Hant.java_lesson5_ex9_slide1_content:
Java 7's Files class makes file operations easy.

Like automatic doors - easier than manual!
zh-Hant.java_lesson5_ex9_slide2_content:
Files.readAllLines(path)  // Read all lines
Files.readString(path)    // Read as string
Files.write(path, lines)  // Write
Files.exists(path)        // Check existence
zh-Hant.java_lesson5_ex10_slide1_content:
Use | to catch multiple exception types together.

'If apple OR orange falls, catch it!'
zh-Hant.java_lesson4_ex10_slide3_content:
Deque
